Text

﻿KING [SOLOMON]90-solomon 'S MINES

by

[H. RIDER HAGGARD]91-h. rider haggard

DEDICATION

This faithful but unpretending record of a remarkable adventure is hereby respectfully dedicated by [the narrator]234-the narrator ,

[ALLAN QUATERMAIN]92-allan quatermain ,

to all [the big and little boys who read it]235-the big and little boys who read it .

[AUTHOR]236-author 'S NOTE

[The author]237-the author ventures to take this opportunity to thank [[his]237-the author readers]238-his readers for the kind reception [they]238-his readers have accorded to the successive editions of this tale during the last twelve years . [He]237-the author hopes that in its present form it will fall into the hands of [an even wider public]239-an even wider public , and that in years to come it may continue to afford amusement to [those who are still young enough at heart to love a story of treasure , war , and wild adventure]240-those who are still young enough at heart to love a story of treasure , war , and wild adventure .

[Ditchingham]1-ditchingham , 11 March , 1898 .

POST SCRIPTUM

Now , in 1907 , on the occasion of the issue of this edition , [I]0-i can only add how glad [I]0-i am that [my]0-i romance should continue to please [so many readers]241-so many readers . Imagination has been verified by fact ; the King Solomon 's Mines [I]0-i dreamed of have been discovered , and are putting out [their]242-their gold once more , and , according to the latest reports , [their]242-their diamonds also ; [the Kukuanas]93-the kukuanas or , rather , [the Matabele]94-the matabele , have been tamed by [the white man]243-the white man 's bullets , but still there seem to be [many who find pleasure in these simple pages]244-many who find pleasure in these simple pages . That [they]244-many who find pleasure in these simple pages may continue so to do , even to [the third and fourth generation]245-the third and fourth generation , or perhaps longer still , would , [I]0-i am sure , be the hope of [[our]246-our old and departed friend]247-our old and departed friend , [Allan Quatermain]92-allan quatermain .

[H. Rider Haggard]91-h. rider haggard . [Ditchingham]1-ditchingham , 1907 .

INTRODUCTION

Now that this book is printed , and about to be given to [the world]248-the world , a sense of its shortcomings both in style and contents , weighs very heavily upon [me]0-i . As regards the latter , [I]0-i can only say that it does not pretend to be a full account of everything [we]246-our did and saw . There are many things connected with [our]246-our journey into [Kukuanaland]2-kukuanaland that [I]0-i should have liked to dwell upon at length , which , as it is , have been scarcely alluded to . Amongst these are the curious legends which [I]0-i collected about the chain armour that saved [us]246-our from destruction in the great battle of [Loo]3-loo , and also about the " Silent Ones "[95-colossi] or [Colossi]95-colossi at [the mouth of [the stalactite cave]250-the stalactite cave]249-the mouth of the stalactite cave . Again , if [I]0-i had given way to [my]0-i own impulses , [I]0-i should have wished to go into the differences , some of which are to [my]0-i mind very suggestive , between the Zulu and Kukuana dialects . Also a few pages might have been given up profitably to the consideration of the indigenous flora and fauna of [Kukuanaland]2-kukuanaland . 1 Then there remains the most interesting subject - that , as it is , has only been touched on incidentally - of the magnificent system of military organisation in force in [that country]251-that country , which , in [my]0-i opinion , is much superior to that inaugurated by [Chaka]96-chaka in [Zululand]4-zululand , inasmuch as it permits of even more rapid mobilisation , and does not necessitate the employment of the pernicious system of enforced celibacy . Lastly , [I]0-i have scarcely spoken of the domestic and family customs of [the Kukuanas]93-the kukuanas , many of which are exceedingly quaint , or of [their]93-the kukuanas proficiency in the art of smelting and welding metals . This science [they]93-the kukuanas carry to considerable perfection , of which a good example is to be seen in [their]93-the kukuanas " tollas , "[252-captain good] or heavy throwing knives , the backs of these weapons being made of hammered iron , and the edges of beautiful steel welded with great skill on to the iron frames . The fact of the matter is , [I]0-i thought , with [Sir Henry Curtis]97-sir henry and [Captain Good]252-captain good , that the best plan would be to tell [my]0-i story in a plain , straightforward manner , and to leave these matters to be dealt with subsequently in whatever way ultimately may appear to be desirable . In the meanwhile [I]0-i shall , of course , be delighted to give all information in [my]0-i power to anybody interested in such things .

And now it only remains for [me]0-i to offer apologies for [my]0-i blunt way of writing . [I]0-i can but say in excuse of it that [I]0-i am more accustomed to handle a rifle than a pen , and can not make any pretence to the grand literary flights and flourishes which [I]0-i see in novels - for sometimes [I]0-i like to read a novel . [I]0-i suppose they - the flights and flourishes - are desirable , and [I]0-i regret not being able to supply them ; but at the same time [I]0-i can not help thinking that simple things are always the most impressive , and that books are easier to understand when they are written in plain language , though perhaps [I]0-i have no right to set up an opinion on such a matter . " A sharp spear , "[0-i] runs the Kukuana saying , " needs no polish "[0-i] ; and on the same principle [I]0-i venture to hope that a true story , however strange it may be , does not require to be decked out in fine words .

Allan Quatermain .

1 [I]0-i discovered eight varieties of antelope , with which [I]0-i was previously totally unacquainted , and many new species of plants , for the most part of the bulbous tribe . - A.Q.

CONTENTS

I [I]0-i MEET [SIR HENRY CURTIS]97-sir henry II THE LEGEND OF [SOLOMON]90-solomon 'S MINES III [UMBOPA]6-umbopa ENTERS [OUR]253-we SERVICE IV [AN ELEPHANT HUNT V]254-an elephant hunt v [OUR]253-we MARCH INTO [THE DESERT VI WATER]7-the desert vi water ! [WATER]8-water ! VII [SOLOMON]90-solomon 'S ROAD VIII [WE]253-we [ENTER KUKUANALAND IX TWALA THE KING X THE WITCH - HUNT XI]255-enter kukuanaland ix twala the king x the witch - hunt xi [WE]253-we GIVE A SIGN XII BEFORE [THE BATTLE XIII THE ATTACK XIV THE LAST STAND OF THE GREYS XV GOOD FALLS SICK XVI THE PLACE OF DEATH XVII SOLOMON 'S TREASURE CHAMBER XVIII]256-the battle xiii the attack xiv the last stand of the greys xv good falls sick xvi the place of death xvii solomon 's treasure chamber xviii [WE]253-we ABANDON [HOPE XIX IGNOSI 'S FAREWELL XX FOUND

KING SOLOMON 'S MINES

CHAPTER]9-hope xix ignosi 's farewell xx found king solomon 's mines chapter I

[I]0-i MEET [SIR HENRY CURTIS]97-sir henry

It is a curious thing that at [my]0-i age - fifty - five last birthday - [I]0-i should find [myself]0-i taking up a pen to try to write a history . [I]0-i wonder what sort of a history it will be when [I]0-i have finished it , if ever [I]0-i come to the end of the trip ! [I]0-i have done a good many things in [my]0-i life , which seems a long one to [me]0-i , owing to [my]0-i having begun work so young , perhaps . At an age when [other boys]257-other boys are at [school]258-school [I]0-i was earning [my]0-i living as [a trader in [the old Colony]260-the old colony]259-a trader in the old colony . [I]0-i have been trading , hunting , fighting , or mining ever since . And yet it is only eight months ago that [I]0-i made [my]0-i pile . It is a big pile now that [I]0-i have got it - [I]0-i do n't yet know how big - but [I]0-i do not think [I]0-i would go through the last fifteen or sixteen months again for it ; no , not if [I]0-i knew that [I]0-i should come out safe at the end , pile and all . But then [I]0-i am [a timid man]261-a timid man , and dislike violence ; moreover , [I]0-i am almost sick of adventure . [I]0-i wonder why [I]0-i am going to write this book : it is not in [my]0-i line . [I]0-i am not [a literary man]262-a literary man , though very devoted to the Old Testament and also to the " Ingoldsby Legends . "[262-a literary man] Let [me]0-i try to set down [my]0-i reasons , just to see if [I]0-i have any .

First reason : Because [Sir Henry Curtis]97-sir henry and [Captain John Good]98-good asked [me]0-i .

Second reason : Because [I]0-i am laid up here at [Durban]10-durban with the pain in [my]0-i left leg . Ever since that confounded lion got hold of [me]0-i [I]0-i have been liable to this trouble , and being rather bad just now , it makes [me]0-i limp more than ever . There must be some poison in a lion 's teeth , otherwise how is it that when [your]263-your wounds are healed they break out again , generally , mark [you]263-your , at the same time of year that [you]263-your got [your]263-your mauling ? It is a hard thing when one has shot [sixty - five lions or more]264-sixty - five lions or more , as [I]0-i have in the course of [my]0-i life , that the sixty - sixth should chew [your]263-your leg like a quid of tobacco . It breaks the routine of the thing , and putting other considerations aside , [I]0-i am [an orderly man]265-an orderly man and do n't like that . This is by the way .

Third reason : Because [I]0-i want [[[my]0-i boy]266-my boy [Harry]97-sir henry , who is over there at [the hospital in [London]11-london]268-the hospital in london studying to become [a doctor]269-a doctor , to have something to amuse [him]266-my boy and keep [him]266-my boy out of mischief for a week or so]267-my boy harry , who is over there at the hospital in london studying to become a doctor , to have something to amuse him and keep him out of mischief for a week or so . Hospital work must sometimes pall and grow rather dull , for even of cutting up dead bodies there may come satiety , and as this history will not be dull , whatever else it may be , it will put a little life into things for a day or two while [Harry]97-sir henry is reading of [our]270-our adventures .

Fourth reason and last : Because [I]0-i am going to tell the strangest story that [I]0-i remember . It may seem a queer thing to say , especially considering that there is [no woman in it]271-no woman in it - except [Foulata]99-foulata . Stop , though ! there is [Gagaoola]100-gagaoola , if [she]100-gagaoola was [a woman]272-a woman , and not [a fiend]273-a fiend . But [she]100-gagaoola was a hundred at least , and therefore not marriageable , so [I]0-i do n't count [her]100-gagaoola . At any rate , [I]0-i can safely say that there is not a petticoat in the whole history .

Well , [I]0-i had better come to the yoke . [It]274-it is [a stiff place]275-a stiff place , and [I]0-i feel as though [I]0-i were bogged up to the axle . But , " sutjes , sutjes , "[276-the boers] as [the Boers]276-the boers say - [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i do n't know how [they]276-the boers spell it - softly does it . [A strong team]277-a strong team will come through at last , that is , if [they]277-a strong team are not too poor . [You]278-you can never do anything with [poor oxen]279-poor oxen . Now to make a start .

[I]0-i , [Allan Quatermain]92-allan quatermain , of [Durban]10-durban , [Natal]12-natal , [Gentleman]280-gentleman , make oath and say - That 's how [I]0-i headed [my]0-i deposition before [the magistrate]281-the magistrate about [poor Khiva]101-khiva 's and [Ventv"gel]101-khiva 's sad deaths ; but somehow it does n't seem quite the right way to begin a book . And , besides , am [I]2611-niggers [a gentleman]2609-a gentleman ? What is [a gentleman]2609-a gentleman ? [I]2611-niggers do n't quite know , and yet [I]2611-niggers have had to do with [niggers]2611-niggers - no , [I]2611-niggers will scratch out that word "[2611-niggers] [niggers]2611-niggers , " for [I]2611-niggers do not like it . [I]2611-niggers 've known [natives who are]2612-natives who are , and so [you]2613-you will say , [Harry]97-sir henry , [[my]2611-niggers boy]266-my boy , before [you]2613-you have done with this tale , and [I]2611-niggers have known [mean whites with lots of money and fresh out from [home]2616-home , too , who are not]2615-mean whites with lots of money and fresh out from home , too , who are not .[2611-niggers]

At any rate , [I]0-i was born [a gentleman]2609-a gentleman , though [I]0-i have been nothing but [a poor travelling trader and hunter]284-a poor travelling trader and hunter all [my]0-i life . Whether [I]0-i have remained so [I]0-i known not , [you]285-you must judge of that . Heaven knows [I]0-i 've tried . [I]0-i have killed [many men]286-many men in [my]0-i time , yet [I]0-i have never slain wantonly or stained [my]0-i hand in innocent blood , but only in self - defence . [The Almighty]102-god gave [us]287-us [our]287-us lives , and [I]0-i suppose [He]102-god meant [us]287-us to defend [them]288-them , at least [I]0-i have always acted on that , and [I]0-i hope it will not be brought up against [me]0-i when [my]0-i clock strikes . There , there , it is [a cruel and a wicked world]289-a cruel and a wicked world , and for [a timid man]261-a timid man [I]0-i have been mixed up in a great deal of fighting . [I]0-i can not tell the rights of it , but at any rate [I]0-i have never stolen , though once [I]0-i cheated [a Kafir]291-a kafir out of a herd of cattle . But then [he]291-a kafir had done [me]0-i a dirty turn , and it has troubled [me]0-i ever since into the bargain .

Well , it is eighteen months or so ago since first [I]0-i met [Sir Henry Curtis]97-sir henry and [Captain Good]98-good . It was in this way . [I]0-i had been up elephant hunting beyond [Bamangwato]13-bamangwato , and had met with bad luck . Everything went wrong that trip , and to top up with [I]0-i got the fever badly . So soon as [I]0-i was well enough [I]0-i trekked down to [the Diamond Fields]292-the diamond fields , sold such ivory as [I]0-i had , together with [[my]0-i wagon]293-my wagon and [oxen]294-oxen , discharged [[my]0-i hunters]295-my hunters , and took [the post - cart]296-the post - cart to [the Cape]14-the cape . After spending a week in [Cape Town]15-cape town , finding that [they]297-they overcharged [me]0-i at [the hotel]298-the hotel , and having seen everything there was to see , including [the botanical gardens]299-the botanical gardens , which seem to [me]0-i likely to confer a great benefit on [the country]300-the country , and [the new Houses of Parliament]301-the new houses of parliament , which [I]0-i expect will do nothing of the sort , [I]0-i determined to go back to [Natal]12-natal by [the Dunkeld]16-the dunkeld , then lying at [the docks]302-the docks waiting for the [Edinburgh Castle]17-edinburgh castle due in from [England]18-england . [I]0-i took [my]0-i berth and went aboard , and that afternoon [the Natal passengers from the [Edinburgh Castle]17-edinburgh castle]303-the natal passengers from the edinburgh castle transhipped , and [we]304-we weighed and put to [sea]305-sea .

Among [these passengers who came on board]306-these passengers who came on board were two who excited [my]0-i curiosity . One , [a gentleman of about thirty]307-a gentleman of about thirty , was perhaps [the biggest - chested and longest - armed man [I]0-i ever saw]308-the biggest - chested and longest - armed man i ever saw . [He]307-a gentleman of about thirty had yellow hair , a thick yellow beard , clear - cut features , and large grey eyes set deep in [his]307-a gentleman of about thirty head . [I]0-i never saw [a finer - looking man]309-a finer - looking man , and somehow [he]307-a gentleman of about thirty reminded [me]0-i of [an ancient Dane]310-an ancient dane . Not that [I]0-i know much of [ancient Danes]103-ancient danes , though [I]0-i knew [a modern Dane]311-a modern dane who did [me]0-i out of ten pounds ; but [I]0-i remember once seeing a picture of [some of [those gentry]313-those gentry]312-some of those gentry , who , [I]0-i take it , were [a kind of white Zulus]314-a kind of white zulus . [They]312-some of those gentry were drinking out of big horns , and [their]312-some of those gentry long hair hung down [their]312-some of those gentry backs . As [I]0-i looked at [[my]0-i friend]315-my friend standing there by the companion - ladder , [I]0-i thought that if [he]315-my friend only let [his]315-my friend grow a little , put one of those chain shirts on to [his]315-my friend great shoulders , and took hold of a battle - axe and a horn mug , [he]315-my friend might have sat as a model for that picture . And by the way it is a curious thing , and just shows how the blood will out , [I]0-i discovered afterwards that [Sir Henry Curtis]97-sir henry , for that was [the big man]316-the big man 's name , is of Danish blood . 1 [He]316-the big man also reminded [me]0-i strongly of [somebody else]317-somebody else , but at the time [I]0-i could not remember who it was .

[The other man]318-the other man , who stood talking to [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , was stout and dark , and of quite a different cut . [I]0-i suspected at once that [he]318-the other man was [a naval officer]319-a naval officer ; [I]0-i do n't know why , but it is difficult to mistake [a navy man]320-a navy man . [I]0-i have gone shooting trips with several of [them]321-them in the course of [my]0-i life , and [they]321-them have always proved [themselves]321-them [the best and bravest and nicest fellows [I]0-i ever met]322-the best and bravest and nicest fellows i ever met , though sadly given , some of [them]321-them , to the use of profane language . [I]0-i asked a page or two back , what is [a gentleman]2609-a gentleman ? [I]0-i 'll answer the question now : [A Royal Naval officer]324-a royal naval officer is , in a general sort of way , though of course there may be a black sheep among [them]324-a royal naval officer here and there . [I]0-i fancy it is just [the wide seas]325-the wide seas and the breath of [God]102-god 's winds that wash [their]324-a royal naval officer hearts and blow the bitterness out of [their]324-a royal naval officer minds and make [them]324-a royal naval officer what [men]326-men ought to be .

Well , to return , [I]0-i proved right again ; [I]0-i ascertained that [the dark man]327-the dark man was [a naval officer]319-a naval officer , [a lieutenant of thirty - one]329-a lieutenant of thirty - one , who , after seventeen years ' service , had been turned out of [[her]330-her Majesty]331-her majesty 's employ with the barren honour of [a commander]332-a commander 's rank , because it was impossible that [he]327-the dark man should be promoted . This is what [people who serve [the Queen]334-the queen]333-people who serve the queen have to expect : to be shot out into [the cold world]335-the cold world to find a living just when [they]333-people who serve the queen are beginning really to understand [their]333-people who serve the queen work , and to reach the prime of life . [I]0-i suppose [they]333-people who serve the queen do n't mind it , but for [my]0-i own part [I]0-i had rather earn [my]0-i bread as [a hunter]336-a hunter . [One]337-one 's halfpence are as scarce perhaps , but [you]338-you do not get so many kicks .

[The officer]339-the officer 's name [I]0-i found out - by referring to [the passengers]340-the passengers ' lists - was Good - [Captain John Good]98-good . [He]98-good was broad , of medium height , dark , stout , and rather [a curious man to look at]341-a curious man to look at . [He]98-good was so very neat and so very clean - shaved , and [he]98-good always wore an eye - glass in [his]98-good right eye . It seemed to grow there , for it had no string , and [he]98-good never took it out except to wipe it . At first [I]0-i thought [he]98-good used to sleep in it , but afterwards [I]0-i found that this was a mistake . [He]98-good put it in [his]98-good trousers pocket when [he]98-good went to bed , together with [his]98-good false teeth , of which [he]98-good had two beautiful sets that , [my]0-i own being none of the best , have often caused [me]0-i to break the tenth commandment . But [I]0-i am anticipating .

Soon after [we]342-we had got under way evening closed in , and brought with it very dirty weather . A keen breeze sprung up off [land]343-land , and a kind of aggravated Scotch mist soon drove [everybody]344-everybody from [the deck]345-the deck . As for [the Dunkeld]16-the dunkeld , [she]16-the dunkeld is [a flat - bottomed punt]346-a flat - bottomed punt , and going up light as [she]16-the dunkeld was , [she]16-the dunkeld rolled very heavily . It almost seemed as though [she]16-the dunkeld would go right over , but [she]16-the dunkeld never did . It was quite impossible to walk about , so [I]0-i stood near the engines where it was warm , and amused [myself]0-i with watching the pendulum , which was fixed opposite to [me]0-i , swinging slowly backwards and forwards as [the vessel]347-the vessel rolled , and marking the angle [she]16-the dunkeld touched at each lurch .

" That pendulum 's wrong ; it is not properly weighted , "[348-the naval officer whom i had noticed when the passengers came aboard] suddenly said a somewhat testy voice at [my]0-i shoulder . Looking round [I]0-i saw [the naval officer whom [I]0-i had noticed when [the passengers]340-the passengers came aboard]348-the naval officer whom i had noticed when the passengers came aboard .

" Indeed , now what makes [you]348-the naval officer whom i had noticed when the passengers came aboard think so ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" Think so . [I]16-the dunkeld do n't think at all . Why there "[16-the dunkeld] - as [she]16-the dunkeld righted [herself]16-the dunkeld after a roll - " if [the ship]2617-the ship had really rolled to the degree that thing pointed to , then [she]2617-the ship would never have rolled again , that 's all . But it is just like [these merchant skippers]2618-these merchant skippers , [they]2618-these merchant skippers are always so confoundedly careless . "[16-the dunkeld]

Just then the dinner - bell rang , and [I]0-i was not sorry , for it is a dreadful thing to have to listen to [an officer of the Royal Navy]350-an officer of the royal navy when [he]350-an officer of the royal navy gets on to that subject . [I]0-i only know one worse thing , and that is to hear [a merchant skipper]351-a merchant skipper express [his]351-a merchant skipper candid opinion of [officers of [the Royal Navy]20-the royal navy]352-officers of the royal navy .

[Captain Good]98-good and [I]0-i went down to dinner together , and there [we]353-we found [Sir Henry Curtis]97-sir henry already seated . [He]97-sir henry and [Captain Good]98-good were placed together , and [I]0-i sat opposite to [them]354-them . [The captain]355-the captain and [I]0-i soon fell into talk about shooting and what not ; [he]97-sir henry asking [me]0-i many questions , for [he]97-sir henry is very inquisitive about all sorts of things , and [I]0-i answering them as well as [I]0-i could . Presently [he]97-sir henry got on to elephants .

" Ah , [sir]2619-sir , "[356-somebody who was sitting near me] called out [somebody who was sitting near [me]0-i]356-somebody who was sitting near me , " [you]2619-sir 've reached [the right man]2620-the right man for that ; [Hunter Quatermain]105-quatermain should be able to tell [you]2619-sir about elephants if [anybody]2621-anybody can . "[356-somebody who was sitting near me]

[Sir Henry]97-sir henry , who had been sitting quite quiet listening to [our]357-our talk , started visibly .

" Excuse [me]97-sir henry , [sir]2619-sir , "[97-sir henry] [he]97-sir henry said , leaning forward across the table , and speaking in a low deep voice , a very suitable voice , it seemed to [me]0-i , to come out of those great lungs . " Excuse [me]97-sir henry , [sir]2619-sir , but is [your]2619-sir name [Allan Quatermain]92-allan quatermain ? "[97-sir henry]

[I]0-i said that it was .

[The big man]316-the big man made no further remark , but [I]0-i heard [him]316-the big man mutter " fortunate "[316-the big man] into [his]316-the big man beard .

Presently dinner came to an end , and as [we]357-our were leaving [the saloon]359-the saloon [Sir Henry]97-sir henry strolled up and asked [me]0-i if [I]0-i would come into [[his]97-sir henry cabin]360-his cabin to smoke a pipe . " [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry Curtis]97-sir henry , when [the man]371-the man had brought the whisky and lit the lamp , " the year before last about this time , [you]107-quatermain were , [I]97-sir henry believe , at [a place called [Bamangwato]13-bamangwato]2624-a place called bamangwato , to [the north of [the Transvaal]21-the transvaal]2625-the north of the transvaal . "[97-sir henry]

" [I]0-i was , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , rather surprised that [this gentleman]372-this gentleman should be so well acquainted with [my]0-i movements , which were not , so far as [I]0-i was aware , considered of general interest .

" [You]107-quatermain were trading [there]2626-there , were [you]107-quatermain not ? "[98-good] put in [Captain Good]98-good , in [his]98-good quick way .

" [I]98-good was . [I]98-good took up [a wagon - load of goods]2627-a wagon - load of goods , made a camp outside [the settlement]2628-the settlement , and stopped till [I]98-good had sold [them]2627-a wagon - load of goods . "[98-good]

[Sir Henry]97-sir henry was sitting opposite to [me]0-i in a Madeira chair , [his]97-sir henry arms leaning on the table . [He]97-sir henry now looked up , fixing [his]97-sir henry large grey eyes full upon [my]0-i face . There was a curious anxiety in them , [I]0-i thought .

"[97-sir henry]

" Yes . "[98-good]

Then came a pause .

"[97-sir henry]

" [I]0-i heard something , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , and stopped . The subject was one which [I]0-i did not care to discuss .

" [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , "[374-the former] went on [the former]374-the former , " [I]374-the former am going to tell [you]107-quatermain a story , and ask [your]107-quatermain advice , and perhaps [your]107-quatermain assistance . " [Mr. Neville]108-neville was [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother . "[97-sir henry]

" [He]376-his brother was , "[97-sir henry] went on [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , " [[my]97-sir henry only and [younger brother]2650-younger brother]2649-my only and younger brother , and till five years ago [I]97-sir henry do not suppose that [we]2651-we were ever a month away from [each other]373-each other . Here [Captain Good]98-good nodded [his]98-good head vigorously to [himself]98-good . [The ship]2617-the ship gave a big roll just then , so that the looking - glass , which was fixed opposite [us]379-us to starboard , was for a moment nearly over [our]379-us heads , and as [I]0-i was sitting with [my]0-i hands in [my]0-i pockets and staring upwards , [I]0-i could see [him]98-good nodding like anything .

" As [I]97-sir henry daresay [you]97-sir henry know , "[97-sir henry] went on [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , " if [a man]2655-a man dies intestate , and has no property but [land]343-land , real property it is called in [England]18-england , it all descends to [[his]2655-a man eldest son]2657-his eldest son . It so happened that just at the time when [we]379-us quarrelled [[our]379-us father]2658-our father died intestate . [He]2655-a man had put off making [his]2655-a man will until it was too late . The result was that [[my]97-sir henry brother , who had not been brought up to any profession]2659-my brother , who had not been brought up to any profession , was left without a penny . Of course it would have been [my]97-sir henry duty to provide for [him]98-good , but at the time the quarrel between [us]379-us was so bitter that [I]97-sir henry did not - to [my]97-sir henry shame [I]97-sir henry say it and [he]98-good sighed deeply - offer to do anything . It was not that [I]97-sir henry grudged [him]98-good justice , but [I]97-sir henry waited for [him]98-good to make advances , and [he]98-good made none . [I]97-sir henry am sorry to trouble [you]0-i with all this , [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , but [I]97-sir henry must to make things clear , eh , [Good]98-good ? "[97-sir henry]

" Quite so , quite so , "[355-the captain] said [the captain]355-the captain . " [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain will , [I]355-the captain am sure , keep this history to [himself]107-quatermain . "[355-the captain]

" Of course , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , for [I]0-i rather pride [myself]0-i on [my]0-i discretion , for which , as [Sir Henry]97-sir henry had heard , [I]0-i have some repute .

" Well , "[97-sir henry] went on [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , " [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother had a few hundred pounds to [his]2648-my brother account at the time . Without saying anything to [me]97-sir henry [he]2648-my brother drew out this paltry sum , and , having adopted the name of [Neville]108-neville , started off for [South Africa]23-south africa in the wild hope of making a fortune . This [I]97-sir henry learned afterwards . Some three years passed , and [I]97-sir henry heard nothing of [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother , though [I]97-sir henry wrote several times . Doubtless the letters never reached [him]2648-my brother . But as time went on [I]97-sir henry grew more and more troubled about [him]2648-my brother . [I]97-sir henry found out , [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , that blood is thicker than water . "[97-sir henry]

" That 's true , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , thinking of [[my]0-i boy]266-my boy [Harry]97-sir henry .

" [I]97-sir henry found out , [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , that [I]97-sir henry would have given half [my]97-sir henry fortune to know that [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother [George]110-george curtis , [the only relation [I]97-sir henry possess]2663-the only relation i possess , was safe and well , and that [I]97-sir henry should see [him]110-george curtis again . "[97-sir henry]

" But [you]107-quatermain never did , [Curtis]110-george curtis , "[98-good] jerked out [Captain Good]98-good , glancing at [the big man]316-the big man 's face .

" Well , [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , as time went on [I]97-sir henry became more and more anxious to find out if [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother was alive or dead , and if alive to get [him]110-george curtis [home]2616-home again . [I]97-sir henry set enquiries on foot , and [your]107-quatermain letter was one of the results . "[97-sir henry]

" Yes , "[355-the captain] said [the captain]355-the captain ; " nothing else to do , [you]107-quatermain see . "[355-the captain]

1 [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain 's ideas about [ancient Danes]103-ancient danes seem to be rather confused ; [we]384-us have always understood that [they]103-ancient danes were [dark - haired people]385-dark - haired people . Probably [he]107-quatermain was thinking of [Saxons]111-saxons . - [Editor]112-editor .

CHAPTER II

THE LEGEND OF [SOLOMON 'S MINES]90-solomon

" What was it that [you]107-quatermain heard about [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother 's journey at [Bamangwato]13-bamangwato ? "[97-sir henry] asked [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , as [I]0-i paused to fill [my]0-i pipe before replying to [Captain Good]98-good .

" [I]0-i heard this , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , " and [I]0-i have never mentioned it to [a soul]2671-a soul till to - day . [I]0-i heard that [he]2648-my brother was starting for [[Solomon]90-solomon 's Mines]2672-solomon 's mines . "[0-i]

" [[Solomon]90-solomon 's Mines]2672-solomon 's mines ? "[386-my hearers] ejaculated both [[my]0-i hearers]386-my hearers at once . " Where are [they]2672-solomon 's mines ? "[386-my hearers]

" [I]0-i do n't know , "[0-i] [I]0-i said ; " [I]0-i know where [they]2672-solomon 's mines are said to be . Once [I]0-i saw the peaks of [the mountains that border [them]2672-solomon 's mines]2674-the mountains that border them , but there were [a hundred and thirty miles of desert between [me]0-i and [them]2672-solomon 's mines]2675-a hundred and thirty miles of desert between me and them , and [I]0-i am not aware that [any white man]2676-any white man ever got across [it]2672-solomon 's mines save one . But perhaps the best thing [I]0-i can do is to tell [you]2677-you the legend of [[Solomon]90-solomon 's Mines]2672-solomon 's mines as [I]0-i know it , [you]2677-you passing [your]2677-you word not to reveal anything [I]0-i tell [you]2677-you without [my]0-i permission . Do [you]2677-you agree to that ? [I]0-i have [my]0-i reasons for asking . "[0-i]

[Sir Henry]97-sir henry nodded , and [Captain Good]98-good replied , " Certainly , certainly . "[98-good]

" Well , "[0-i] [I]0-i began , " as [you]2677-you may guess , generally speaking , [elephant hunters]2679-elephant hunters are [a rough set of men , who do not trouble [themselves]2679-elephant hunters with much beyond the facts of life and the ways of [Kafirs]145-the kafirs]2680-a rough set of men , who do not trouble themselves with much beyond the facts of life and the ways of kafirs . But here and there [you]2677-you meet [a man who takes the trouble to collect traditions from [the natives]2682-the natives , and tries to make out a little piece of the history of [this dark land]2683-this dark land]2681-a man who takes the trouble to collect traditions from the natives , and tries to make out a little piece of the history of this dark land . It was such [a man as this]2684-a man as this who first told [me]0-i the legend of [Solomon 's Mines]25-solomon 's mines , now a matter of nearly thirty years ago . That was when [I]0-i was on [my]0-i first elephant hunt in [the Matabele country]2639-the matabele country . [His]2684-a man as this name was [Evans]113-evans , and [he]2684-a man as this was killed the following year , [poor fellow]2686-poor fellow , by a wounded buffalo , and lies buried near [the Zambesi Falls]26-the zambesi falls . [I]0-i was telling [Evans]113-evans one night , [I]0-i remember , of some wonderful workings [I]0-i had found whilst hunting [koodoo]27-koodoo and eland in what is now [the Lydenburg district of [the Transvaal]2688-the transvaal]2687-the lydenburg district of the transvaal . [I]0-i see [they]2689-they have come across these workings again lately in prospecting for gold , but [I]0-i knew of them years ago . There is [a great wide wagon road]2690-a great wide wagon road cut out of [the solid rock]2691-the solid rock , and leading to the mouth of [the working or gallery]2692-the working or gallery . Inside the mouth of [this gallery]2693-this gallery are stacks of gold quartz piled up ready for roasting , which shows that [the workers]2694-the workers , whoever [they]2694-the workers were , must have left in a hurry . Also , about twenty paces in , [the gallery]2695-the gallery is built across , and a beautiful bit of masonry it is . "[0-i]

" ' Ay , ' said [Evans]113-evans , ' but [I]98-good will spin [you]0-i a queerer yarn than that ' ; and [he]113-evans went on to tell [me]98-good how [he]113-evans had found in the far interior [a ruined city , which [he]113-evans believed to be [the Ophir of the Bible]2697-the ophir of the bible]2696-a ruined city , which he believed to be the ophir of the bible , and , by the way , [other more learned men]2698-other more learned men have said the same long since [poor Evans]113-evans 's time . [I]98-good was , [I]98-good remember , listening open - eared to all these wonders , for [I]98-good was young at the time , and this story of an ancient civilisation and of the treasures which [those old Jewish or Phoenician adventurers]2699-those old jewish or phoenician adventurers used to extract from [a country]2700-a country long since lapsed into the darkest barbarism took a great hold upon [my]98-good imagination , when suddenly [he]113-evans said to [me]98-good , ' [Lad]2701-lad , did [you]98-good ever hear of the Suliman Mountains up to [the north - west of [the Mushakulumbwe country]2703-the mushakulumbwe country]2702-the north - west of the mushakulumbwe country ? ' [I]98-good told [him]113-evans [I]98-good never had . ' Ah , well , ' [he]113-evans said , ' that is where [Solomon]90-solomon really had [[his]90-solomon mines]2704-his mines , [[his]90-solomon diamond mines]2705-his diamond mines , [I]98-good mean . '[98-good]

" ' How do [you]113-evans know that ? ' [I]0-i asked .[0-i]

" ' Know it ! why , what is "[98-good] [Suliman]118-suliman " but a corruption of [Solomon]90-solomon ? 1 Besides , [an old Isanusi or witch doctoress]2706-an old isanusi or witch doctoress up in [the Manica country]2707-the manica country told [me]0-i all about it . [She]2706-an old isanusi or witch doctoress said that [the people who lived across [those mountains]2709-those mountains]2708-the people who lived across those mountains were [a "[0-i] branch " of [the Zulus]114-the zulus , speaking a dialect of [Zulu]101-khiva]2710-a " branch " of the zulus , speaking a dialect of zulu , but [finer and bigger men even]2711-finer and bigger men even ; that there lived among [them]2708-the people who lived across those mountains [great wizards , who had learnt [their]2712-great wizards , who had learnt their art from white men when " all the world was dark , " and who had the secret of a wonderful mine of " bright stones art from [white men]2713-white men when "[0-i] all [the world]248-the world was dark , " and who had the secret of [a wonderful mine of "[98-good] bright stones]2714-a wonderful mine of " bright stones]2712-great wizards , who had learnt their art from white men when " all the world was dark , " and who had the secret of a wonderful mine of " bright stones . " '[98-good]

" Well , [I]0-i laughed at this story at the time , though it interested [me]0-i , for [the Diamond Fields]292-the diamond fields were not discovered then , but poor [Evans]113-evans went off and was killed , and for twenty years [I]0-i never thought any more of the matter . However , just twenty years afterwards - and that is a long time , [gentlemen]2716-gentlemen ; [an elephant hunter]2717-an elephant hunter does not often live for twenty years at [his]2717-an elephant hunter business - [I]0-i heard something more definite about [Suliman 's Mountains]29-suliman 's mountains and [the country which lies beyond [them]29-suliman 's mountains]2718-the country which lies beyond them . [I]0-i was up beyond [the Manica country]2707-the manica country , at [a place called [Sitanda 's Kraal]30-sitanda 's kraal]2720-a place called sitanda 's kraal , and [a miserable place it was , for [a man]2655-a man could get nothing to eat]2721-a miserable place it was , for a man could get nothing to eat , and there was but little game about . [I]0-i had an attack of fever , and was in a bad way generally , when one day [a Portugee]2723-a portugee arrived with [a single companion]2724-a single companion - [a half - breed]2725-a half - breed . Now [I]0-i know [[your]2726-your low - class [Delagoa Portugee]31-delagoa portugee]2727-your low - class delagoa portugee well . There is no greater devil unhung in a general way , battening as [he]2723-a portugee does upon human agony and flesh in the shape of [slaves]2728-slaves . But this was quite [a different type of man to [the mean fellows whom [I]0-i had been accustomed to meet]2730-the mean fellows whom i had been accustomed to meet]2729-a different type of man to the mean fellows whom i had been accustomed to meet ; indeed , in appearance [he]2723-a portugee reminded [me]0-i more of [the polite doms [I]0-i have read about]2731-the polite doms i have read about , for [he]2723-a portugee was tall and thin , with large dark eyes and curling grey mustachios . [We]2732-we talked together for a while , for [he]2723-a portugee could speak broken English , and [I]0-i understood a little [Portugee]115-portugee , and [he]2723-a portugee told [me]0-i that [his]2723-a portugee name was [José Silvestre]116-silvestre , and that [he]2723-a portugee had [a place near [Delagoa Bay]32-delagoa bay]2733-a place near delagoa bay . When [he]2723-a portugee went on next day with [[his]2723-a portugee half - breed companion]2734-his half - breed companion , [he]2723-a portugee said ' Good - bye , ' taking off [his]2723-a portugee hat quite in the old style .[0-i]

" ' Good - bye , [senor]2735-senor , ' [he]2723-a portugee said ; ' if ever [we]2732-we meet again [I]98-good shall be [the richest man in [the world]248-the world]2736-the richest man in the world , and [I]98-good will remember [you]2735-senor . ' [I]98-good laughed a little - [I]98-good was too weak to laugh much - and watched [him]2723-a portugee strike out for [the great desert to the west]2738-the great desert to the west , wondering if [he]2723-a portugee was mad , or what [he]2723-a portugee thought [he]2723-a portugee was going to find [there]2626-there .[98-good]

" A week passed , and [I]0-i got the better of [my]0-i fever . One evening [I]0-i was sitting on the ground in front of [the little tent]2740-the little tent [I]0-i had with [me]0-i , chewing the last leg of a miserable fowl [I]0-i had bought from [a native]2741-a native for a bit of cloth worth twenty fowls , and staring at the hot red sun sinking down over [the desert]2742-the desert , when suddenly [I]0-i saw a figure , apparently that of [a European]2743-a european , for [it]2723-a portugee wore a coat , on the slope of [the rising ground opposite to [me]0-i]2744-the rising ground opposite to me , about three hundred yards away . [The figure]2745-the figure crept along on [its]2745-the figure hands and knees , then it got up and staggered forward a few yards on its legs , only to fall and crawl again . Seeing that it must be [somebody in distress]2746-somebody in distress , [I]0-i sent [one of [[my]0-i hunters]295-my hunters]2747-one of my hunters to help [him]2745-the figure , and presently [he]2745-the figure arrived , and who do [you]2749-you suppose it turned out to be ? "[0-i]

" [José Silvestre]116-silvestre , of course , "[98-good] said [Captain Good]98-good .

" Yes , [José Silvestre]116-silvestre , or rather [his]116-silvestre skeleton and a little skin . [His]116-silvestre face was a bright yellow with bilious fever , and [his]116-silvestre large dark eyes stood nearly out of [his]116-silvestre head , for all the flesh had gone . There was nothing but yellow parchment - like skin , white hair , and the gaunt bones sticking up beneath .[0-i]

" ' Water ! for the sake of [Christ]117-christ , water ! ' [he]116-silvestre moaned and [I]0-i saw that [his]116-silvestre lips were cracked , and [his]116-silvestre tongue , which protruded between them , was swollen and blackish .[0-i]

" [I]0-i gave [him]116-silvestre water with a little milk in it , and [he]116-silvestre drank it in great gulps , two quarts or so , without stopping . [I]0-i would not let [him]116-silvestre have any more . Then the fever took [him]116-silvestre again , and [he]116-silvestre fell down and began to rave about [Suliman]118-suliman 's Mountains , and [the diamonds]2750-the diamonds , and [the desert]2742-the desert . [I]0-i carried [him]116-silvestre into [the tent]2752-the tent and did what [I]0-i could for [him]116-silvestre , which was little enough ; but [I]0-i saw how it must end . About eleven o'clock [he]116-silvestre grew quieter , and [I]0-i lay down for a little rest and went to sleep . At dawn [I]0-i woke again , and in the half light saw [Silvestre]116-silvestre sitting up , [a strange , gaunt form]2753-a strange , gaunt form , and gazing out towards [the desert]2742-the desert . Presently the first ray of the sun shot right across [the wide plain]2755-the wide plain before [us]2756-us till it reached the faraway crest of [one of the tallest of [the Suliman Mountains]29-suliman 's mountains more than a hundred miles away]2757-one of the tallest of the suliman mountains more than a hundred miles away .[0-i]

" ' There it is ! ' cried [the dying man in Portuguese]2758-the dying man in portuguese , and pointing with [his]2758-the dying man in portuguese long , thin arm , ' but [I]0-i shall never reach it , never . [No one]2759-no one will ever reach it ! '[0-i]

" Suddenly , [he]116-silvestre paused , and seemed to take a resolution . ' [Friend]2760-friend , ' [he]116-silvestre said , turning towards [me]0-i , ' are [you]2760-friend there ? [My]0-i eyes grow dark . '[0-i]

" ' Yes , ' [I]0-i said ; ' yes , lie down now , and rest . '[0-i]

" ' Ay , ' [he]116-silvestre answered , ' [I]0-i shall rest soon , [I]0-i have time to rest - all eternity . Listen , [I]0-i am dying ! [You]2760-friend have been good to [me]0-i . [I]0-i will give [you]2760-friend the writing . Perhaps [you]2760-friend will get there if [you]2760-friend can live to pass [the desert]2742-the desert , which has killed [[my]0-i poor servant]2762-my poor servant and [me]0-i . '[0-i]

" Then [he]116-silvestre groped in [his]116-silvestre shirt and brought out what [I]0-i thought was a Boer tobacco pouch made of the skin of the Swart - vet - pens or sable antelope . It was fastened with a little strip of hide , what [we]2763-we call a rimpi , and this [he]116-silvestre tried to loose , but could not . [He]116-silvestre handed it to [me]0-i . ' Untie it , ' [he]116-silvestre said . [I]0-i did so , and extracted a bit of torn yellow linen on which something was written in rusty letters . Inside this rag was a paper .[0-i]

" Then [he]116-silvestre went on feebly , for [he]116-silvestre was growing weak : ' The paper has all that is on the linen . It took [me]0-i years to read . Listen : [[my]0-i ancestor]2764-my ancestor , [a political refugee from [Lisbon]34-lisbon]2765-a political refugee from lisbon , and one of [the first Portuguese who landed on [these shores]2767-these shores]2766-the first portuguese who landed on these shores , wrote that when [he]2764-my ancestor was dying on those mountains which [no white foot ever pressed before or since]2768-no white foot ever pressed before or since . [His]2764-my ancestor name was [José da Silvestra]119-josé da silvestra , and [he]2764-my ancestor lived three hundred years ago . [[His]2764-my ancestor slave]2769-his slave , who waited for [him]2764-my ancestor on [this side of [the mountains]2771-the mountains]2770-this side of the mountains , found [him]2764-my ancestor dead , and brought the writing [home]2616-home to [Delagoa]35-delagoa . It has been in [the family]2773-the family ever since , but [none]2774-none have cared to read it , till at last [I]0-i did . And [I]0-i have lost [my]0-i life over it , but another may succeed , and become [the richest man in [the world]248-the world]2736-the richest man in the world - [the richest man in [the world]248-the world]2736-the richest man in the world . Only give it to [no one]2759-no one , [senor]2735-senor ; go [yourself]2735-senor ! '[0-i]

" Then [he]2764-my ancestor began to wander again , and in an hour it was all over .[0-i]

" God rest [him]2764-my ancestor ! [he]2764-my ancestor died very quietly , and [I]0-i buried [him]2764-my ancestor deep , with big boulders on [his]2764-my ancestor breast ; so [I]0-i do not think that [the jackals]2781-the jackals can have dug [him]2764-my ancestor up . And then [I]0-i came away . "[0-i]

" Ay , but the document ? "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , in a tone of deep interest .

" Yes , the document ; what was in it ? "[355-the captain] added [the captain]355-the captain .

" Well , [gentlemen]2716-gentlemen , if [you]2716-gentlemen like [I]0-i will tell [you]2716-gentlemen . [I]0-i have never showed it to [anybody]2621-anybody yet except to [a drunken old Portuguese trader who translated it for [me]0-i , and had forgotten all about it by the next morning]2784-a drunken old portuguese trader who translated it for me , and had forgotten all about it by the next morning . The original rag is at [[my]0-i home in [Durban]10-durban]2785-my home in durban , together with poor [Dom José]120-dom josé 's translation , but [I]0-i have the English rendering in [my]0-i pocket - book , and a facsimile of the map , if it can be called a map . Here it is . "[0-i]

" [I]0-i , [José da Silvestra]119-josé da silvestra , who am now dying of hunger in the little cave where no snow is on the north side of the nipple of [the southernmost of [the two mountains]2787-the two mountains]2786-the southernmost of the two mountains [I]0-i have named [[Sheba]121-sheba 's Breasts]2788-sheba 's breasts , write this in the year 1590 with a cleft bone upon a remnant of [my]0-i raiment , [my]0-i blood being the ink . If [[my]0-i slave]2789-my slave should find it when [he]2789-my slave comes , and should bring it to [Delagoa]35-delagoa , let [[my]0-i friend]315-my friend name illegible bring the matter to the knowledge of [the king]2791-the king , that [he]2791-the king may send an army which , if [they]2792-they live through [the desert]2742-the desert and [the mountains]2771-the mountains , and can overcome [the brave Kukuanes]2795-the brave kukuanes and [their]2795-the brave kukuanes devilish arts , to which end [many priests]2796-many priests should be brought , will make [him]2791-the king [the richest king since [Solomon]90-solomon]2797-the richest king since solomon . With [my]0-i own eyes [I]0-i have seen the countless diamonds stored in [[Solomon]90-solomon 's treasure chamber]2798-solomon 's treasure chamber behind the white Death ; but through the treachery of [Gagool]122-gagool [the witch - finder]2799-the witch - finder [I]0-i might bring nought away , scarcely [my]0-i life . Let [him]2791-the king who comes follow the map , and climb the snow of [Sheba]121-sheba 's left breast till [he]2791-the king reaches the nipple , on the north side of which is [the great road [Solomon]90-solomon made]2800-the great road solomon made , from whence three days ' journey to [the King 's Palace]2801-the king 's palace . Let [him]2791-the king kill [Gagool]122-gagool . Pray for [my]0-i soul . Farewell .[0-i]

[José da Silvestra]119-josé da silvestra . " 2[119-josé da silvestra]

When [I]0-i had finished reading the above , and shown the copy of the map , drawn by the dying hand of [the old Dom]389-the old dom with [his]389-the old dom blood for ink , there followed a silence of astonishment .

" Well , "[98-good] said [Captain Good]98-good , " [I]98-good have been round [the world]248-the world twice , and put in at most ports , but may [I]98-good be hung for [a mutineer]2803-a mutineer if ever [I]98-good heard a yarn like this out of a story book , or in it either , for the matter of that . "[98-good]

" It 's a queer tale , [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry . " [I]97-sir henry suppose [you]107-quatermain are not hoaxing [us]2804-us ? It is , [I]97-sir henry know , sometimes thought allowable to take in a greenhorn . "[97-sir henry]

" If [you]97-sir henry think that , [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , much put out , and pocketing [my]0-i paper - for [I]0-i do not like to be thought one of [those silly fellows who consider it witty to tell lies]390-those silly fellows who consider it witty to tell lies , and who are for ever boasting to [newcomers of extraordinary hunting adventures which never happened]391-newcomers of extraordinary hunting adventures which never happened - " if [you]97-sir henry think that , why , there is an end to the matter , "[0-i] and [I]0-i rose to go .

[Sir Henry]97-sir henry laid [his]97-sir henry large hand upon [my]0-i shoulder . "[97-sir henry]

" [You]97-sir henry shall see the original map and writing when [we]2805-us reach [Durban]10-durban , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , somewhat mollified , for really when [I]0-i came to consider the question it was scarcely wonderful that [he]97-sir henry should doubt [my]0-i good faith .

" But , "[0-i] [I]0-i went on , " [I]0-i have not told [you]97-sir henry about [[your]97-sir henry brother]2806-your brother . That morning on which [Mr. Neville]108-neville was starting [I]0-i saw [Jim]109-jim standing by [[my]0-i wagon]293-my wagon and cutting up tobacco on the disselboom .[0-i]

" ' [Jim]109-jim , ' said [I]0-i , ' where are [you]109-jim off to this trip ? It is elephants ? '[0-i]

" ' No , [Baas]123-baas , ' [he]109-jim answered , ' [we]2813-we are after something worth much more than ivory . '[0-i]

" ' And what might that be ? ' [I]0-i said , for [I]0-i was curious . ' Is it gold ? '[0-i]

" ' No , [Baas]123-baas , something worth more than gold , ' and [he]109-jim grinned .[0-i]

" [I]0-i asked no more questions , for [I]0-i did not like to lower [my]0-i dignity by seeming inquisitive , but [I]0-i was puzzled . [Presently Jim]109-jim finished cutting [his]109-jim tobacco .[0-i]

" ' [Baas]123-baas , ' said [he]109-jim .[0-i]

" [I]0-i took no notice .[0-i]

" ' [Baas]123-baas , ' said [he]109-jim again .[0-i]

" ' [Baas]123-baas , [we]2813-we are going after diamonds . '[0-i]

" ' Diamonds ! why , then , [you]123-baas are steering in the wrong direction ; [you]123-baas should head for [the Fields]36-the fields . '[0-i]

" ' [Baas]123-baas , have [you]123-baas ever heard of [Suliman]118-suliman 's [Berg]37-berg ? ' - that is , [Solomon]90-solomon 's Mountains , [Sir Henry]97-sir henry .[0-i]

" ' Ay ! '[0-i]

" ' [I]0-i have heard a foolish story , [Jim]109-jim . '[0-i]

'[0-i]

" [He]109-jim grinned . ' Mayhap , [Baas]123-baas . [Man]2819-man must die ; [I]395-i 'd rather like to try [a new country]2820-a new country [myself]395-i ; the elephants are getting worked out about here . '[395-i]

" Half an hour after that [I]0-i saw [[Neville]108-neville 's wagon]2824-neville 's wagon move off . [Presently Jim]109-jim came back running . ' Good - bye , [Baas]123-baas , ' [he]109-jim said . ' [I]0-i did n't like to start without bidding [you]123-baas good - bye , for [I]0-i daresay [you]123-baas are right , and that [we]2823-we shall never trek south again . '[0-i]

" ' Is [[your]109-jim master]2818-your master really going to [Suliman]118-suliman 's Berg , [Jim]109-jim , or are [you]109-jim lying ? '[395-i]

" ' Oh ! ' [I]395-i said ; ' wait a bit , [Jim]109-jim ; will [you]109-jim take a note to [[your]109-jim master]2818-your master , [Jim]109-jim , and promise not to give it to [him]2818-your master till [you]109-jim reach [Inyati]22-inyati ? ' which was some hundred miles off .[395-i]

" ' Yes , [Baas]123-baas . '[0-i]

" So [I]395-i took a scrap of paper , and wrote on it , ' Let [him]2818-your master who comes . . . climb [the snow of [Sheba]121-sheba]2827-the snow of sheba 's left breast , till [he]2818-your master reaches the nipple , on the north side of which is [[Solomon]90-solomon 's great road]2828-solomon 's great road . '[395-i]

" ' Now , [Jim]109-jim , ' [I]0-i said , ' when [you]109-jim give this to [[your]109-jim master]2818-your master , tell [him]2818-your master [he]2818-your master had better follow the advice on it implicitly . " [Jim]109-jim took the note and went , and that is all [I]395-i know about [[your]97-sir henry brother]2806-your brother , [Sir Henry]97-sir henry ; but [I]395-i am much afraid - "[395-i]

" [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , " [I]97-sir henry am going to look for [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother ; [I]97-sir henry am going to trace [him]2648-my brother to [Suliman 's Mountains]29-suliman 's mountains , and over them if necessary , till [I]97-sir henry find [him]2648-my brother , or until [I]97-sir henry know that [he]2648-my brother is dead . Will [you]97-sir henry come with [me]97-sir henry ? "[97-sir henry]

[I]0-i am , as [I]0-i think [I]0-i have said , [a cautious man]396-a cautious man , indeed [a timid one]397-a timid one , and this suggestion frightened [me]0-i . It seemed to [me]0-i that to undertake such a journey would be to go to certain death , and putting other considerations aside , as [I]0-i had [a son to support]398-a son to support , [I]0-i could not afford to die just then .

" No , thank [you]97-sir henry , [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , [I]0-i think [I]0-i had rather not , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " [I]0-i am too old for wild - goose chases of that sort , and [we]2834-we should only end up like [[my]0-i poor friend]2835-my poor friend [Silvestre]116-silvestre . [I]0-i have [a son]2836-a son dependent on [me]0-i , so [I]0-i can not afford to risk [my]0-i life foolishly . "[0-i]

Both [Sir Henry]97-sir henry and [Captain Good]98-good looked very disappointed .

" [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , "[374-the former] said [the former]374-the former , " [I]374-the former am well off , and [I]374-the former am bent upon this business . [You]107-quatermain may put the remuneration for [your]107-quatermain services at whatever figure [you]107-quatermain like in reason , and it shall be paid over to [you]107-quatermain before [we]2834-we start . Moreover , [I]374-the former will arrange in the event of anything untoward happening to [us]2834-we or to [you]107-quatermain , that [[your]107-quatermain son]2837-your son shall be suitably provided for . [You]107-quatermain will see from this offer how necessary [I]374-the former think [your]107-quatermain presence . Also if by chance [we]2834-we should reach [this place]2838-this place , and find diamonds , they shall belong to [you]107-quatermain and [Good]98-good equally . [I]374-the former do not want them . But of course that promise is worth nothing at all , though the same thing would apply to any ivory [we]2834-we might get . [You]107-quatermain may pretty well make [your]107-quatermain own terms with [me]374-the former , [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain ; and of course [I]374-the former shall pay all expenses . "[374-the former]

" [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " this is the most liberal proposal [I]0-i ever had , and one not to be sneezed at by [a poor hunter and trader]2839-a poor hunter and trader . But the job is the biggest [I]0-i have come across , and [I]0-i must take time to think it over . [I]0-i will give [you]97-sir henry [my]0-i answer before [we]2840-we get to [Durban]10-durban . "[0-i]

" Very good , "[97-sir henry] answered [Sir Henry]97-sir henry .

Then [I]0-i said good - night and turned in , and dreamt about poor long - dead [Silvestre]116-silvestre and the diamonds .

1 [Suliman]118-suliman is the Arabic form of [Solomon]90-solomon . - [Editor]112-editor .

2 Eu José da Silvestra que estou morrendo de fome ná pequena cova onde não ha neve ao lado norte do bico mais ao sul das duas montanhas que chamei scio de Sheba ; escrevo isto no anno 1590 ; escrevo isto com um pedaço d'"sso n ' um farrapo de minha roupa e com sangue meu por tinta ; se o meu escravo dêr com isto quando venha ao levar para [Lourenzo Marquez]125-lourenzo marquez , que o meu amigo - - - - - leve a cousa ao conhecimento d ' El Rei , para que possa [mandar um exercito que , se desfiler pelo deserto e pelas montonhas e mesmo sobrepujar os bravos Kukuanes e suas artes diabolicas , pelo que se deviam trazer muitos]2841-mandar um exercito que , se desfiler pelo deserto e pelas montonhas e mesmo sobrepujar os bravos kukuanes e suas artes diabolicas , pelo que se deviam trazer muitos padres Far o Rei mais rico depois de Salomão Com meus proprios olhos vé os di amantes sem conto [guardados nas camaras do thesouro de Salomão a traz da morte branca]2842-guardados nas camaras do thesouro de salomão a traz da morte branca , mas pela traição de Gagoal a feiticeira achadora , nada poderia levar , e apenas a minha vida . Quem vier siga o mappa e trepe pela neve de Sheba peito esquerda até chegar ao bica , do lado norte do qual est [a grande estrada do Solomão por elle feita]2843-a grande estrada do solomão por elle feita , donde ha tres dias de jornada até ao Palacio do Rei . Mate Gagoal . Reze por minha alma . Adeos . José da Silvestra .[112-editor]

CHAPTER III

UMBOPA ENTERS [OUR]400-our SERVICE

It takes from four to five days , according to the speed of [the vessel]347-the vessel and the state of the weather , to run up from [the Cape]14-the cape to [Durban]10-durban . Sometimes , if the landing is bad at [East London]38-east london , where [they]402-they have not yet made [that wonderful harbour]403-that wonderful harbour [they]402-they talk so much of , and sink such a mint of money in , [a ship]404-a ship is delayed for twenty - four hours before [the cargo boats]405-the cargo boats can get out to take off the goods . But on this occasion [we]400-our had not to wait at all , for there were [no breakers on the Bar]406-no breakers on the bar to speak of , and the tugs came out at once with the long strings of ugly flat - bottomed boats behind [them]402-they , into which the packages were bundled with a crash . It did not matter what [they]402-they might be , over [they]402-they went slap - bang ; whether they contained china or woollen goods [they]402-they met with the same treatment . [I]0-i saw one case holding four dozen of champagne smashed all to bits , and there was the champagne fizzing and boiling about in the bottom of [the dirty cargo boat]407-the dirty cargo boat . It was a wicked waste , and evidently so [the Kafirs in [the boat]409-the boat]408-the kafirs in the boat thought , for [they]408-the kafirs in the boat found a couple of unbroken bottles , and knocking off the necks drank the contents . But [they]408-the kafirs in the boat had not allowed for the expansion caused by the fizz in the wine , and , feeling [themselves]408-the kafirs in the boat swelling , rolled about in the bottom of [the boat]409-the boat , calling out that the good liquor was " tagati "[0-i] - that is , bewitched . [I]0-i spoke to [them]408-the kafirs in the boat from [the vessel]347-the vessel , and told [them]408-the kafirs in the boat it was [the white man]243-the white man 's strongest medicine , and that [they]408-the kafirs in the boat were as good as [dead men]413-dead men . [Those Kafirs]414-those kafirs went to [the shore]415-the shore in a very great fright , and [I]0-i do not think that [they]414-those kafirs will touch champagne again .

Well , all the time that [we]416-we were steaming up to [Natal]12-natal [I]0-i was thinking over [Sir Henry Curtis]97-sir henry 's offer . [We]416-we did not speak any more on the subject for a day or two , though [I]0-i told [them]408-the kafirs in the boat many hunting yarns , all true ones . There is no need to tell lies about hunting , for so many curious things happen within the knowledge of a man whose business it is to hunt ; but this is by the way .

At last , one beautiful evening in January , which is [our]416-we hottest month , [we]416-we steamed past [the coast of [Natal]12-natal]417-the coast of natal , expecting to make [Durban Point]39-durban point by sunset . It is [a lovely coast all along from [East London]38-east london]418-a lovely coast all along from east london , with [[its]418-a lovely coast all along from east london red sandhills]419-its red sandhills and wide sweeps of vivid green , dotted here and there with [Kafir kraals]132-umbopa , and bordered by a ribbon of white surf , which spouts up in pillars of foam where it hits the rocks . But just before [you]420-you come to [Durban]10-durban there is a peculiar richness about [the landscape]421-the landscape . There are the sheer kloofs cut in [the hills]422-the hills by the rushing rains of centuries , down which [the rivers]423-the rivers sparkle ; there is the deepest green of [the bush]424-the bush , growing as [God]102-god planted [it]424-the bush , and the other greens of [the mealie gardens]425-the mealie gardens and [the sugar patches]426-the sugar patches , while now and again [a white house]427-a white house , smiling out at [the placid sea]428-the placid sea , puts a finish and gives an air of homeliness to the scene . For to [my]0-i mind , however beautiful a view may be , it requires the presence of [man]2819-man to make it complete , but perhaps that is because [I]0-i have lived so much in [the wilderness]430-the wilderness , and therefore know the value of civilisation , though to be sure it drives away the game . [The Garden of Eden]431-the garden of eden , no doubt , looked fair before [man]2819-man was , but [I]0-i always think that it must have been fairer when [Eve]126-eve adorned [it]431-the garden of eden .

To return , [we]433-we had miscalculated a little , and the sun was well down before [we]433-we dropped anchor off [the Point]434-the point , and heard the gun which told [the good folks of [Durban]10-durban]435-the good folks of durban that the English Mail was in . It was too late to think of getting over [the Bar]436-the bar that night , so [we]433-we went comfortably to dinner , after seeing the Mails carried off in [the life - boat]437-the life - boat .

When [we]433-we came up again the moon was out , and shining so brightly over [sea]305-sea and [shore]439-shore that [she]440-she almost paled the quick , large flashes from [the lighthouse]441-the lighthouse . From [the shore]415-the shore floated sweet spicy odours that always remind [me]0-i of hymns and missionaries , and in the windows of [the houses on [the Berea]41-the berea]443-the houses on the berea sparkled a hundred lights . From [a large brig lying near]444-a large brig lying near also came the music of [the sailors]445-the sailors as [they]445-the sailors worked at getting the anchor up in order to be ready for the wind . Altogether it was a perfect night , such a night as [you]446-you sometimes get in [Southern Africa]42-southern africa , and it threw a garment of peace over [everybody]344-everybody as the moon threw a garment of silver over everything . Even the great bulldog , belonging to [a sporting passenger]448-a sporting passenger , seemed to yield to its gentle influences , and forgetting [his]448-a sporting passenger yearning to come to close quarters with the baboon in a cage on the foc'sle , snored happily at the door of [the cabin]368-the cabin , dreaming no doubt that [he]448-a sporting passenger had finished [him]448-a sporting passenger , and happy in [his]448-a sporting passenger dream .

[We]450-we three - that is , [Sir Henry Curtis]97-sir henry , [Captain Good]98-good , and [myself]0-i - went and sat by the wheel , and were quiet for a while .

" Well , [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry presently , " have [you]107-quatermain been thinking about [my]97-sir henry proposals ? "[97-sir henry]

" Ay , "[98-good] echoed [Captain Good]98-good , " what do [you]107-quatermain think of them , [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain ? [I]98-good hope that [you]107-quatermain are going to give [us]450-we the pleasure of [your]107-quatermain company so far as [[Solomon]90-solomon 's Mines]25-solomon 's mines , or wherever [the gentleman [you]107-quatermain knew as [Neville]108-neville may have got to]2844-the gentleman you knew as neville may have got to . "[98-good]

[I]0-i rose and knocked out [my]0-i pipe before [I]0-i answered . [I]0-i had not made up [my]0-i mind , and wanted an additional moment to decide . Before the burning tobacco had fallen into [the sea]451-the sea [I]0-i had decided ; just that little extra second did the trick . It is often the way when [you]452-you have been bothering a long time over a thing .

" Yes , [gentlemen]2716-gentlemen , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , sitting down again , " [I]0-i will go , and by [your]2716-gentlemen leave [I]0-i will tell [you]2716-gentlemen why , and on what conditions . First for the terms which [I]0-i ask .[0-i]

" 1 . [You]2716-gentlemen are to pay all expenses , and any ivory or other valuables [we]2846-we may get is to be divided between [Captain Good]98-good and [myself]0-i .[0-i]

" 2 . That [you]2716-gentlemen give [me]0-i 500 for [my]0-i services on the trip before [we]2846-we start , [I]0-i undertaking to serve [you]2716-gentlemen faithfully till [you]2716-gentlemen choose to abandon the enterprise , or till [we]2846-we succeed , or disaster overtakes [us]2846-we .[0-i]

" 3 . That before [we]2846-we trek [you]2716-gentlemen execute a deed agreeing , in the event of [my]0-i death or disablement , to pay [[my]0-i boy]266-my boy Harry , who is studying medicine over there in [London]11-london , at [[Guy]127-guy 's Hospital]2848-guy 's hospital , a sum of 200 a year for five years , by which time [he]266-my boy ought to be able to earn a living for [himself]266-my boy if [he]266-my boy is worth [his]266-my boy salt . That is all , [I]0-i think , and [I]0-i daresay [you]2716-gentlemen will say quite enough too . "[0-i]

" No , "[97-sir henry] answered [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , " [I]97-sir henry accept [them]2849-them gladly . [I]97-sir henry am bent upon this project , and would pay more than that for [your]2716-gentlemen help , considering the peculiar and exclusive knowledge which [you]2716-gentlemen possess . "[97-sir henry]

" Pity [I]0-i did not ask it , then , but [I]0-i wo n't go back on [my]0-i word . And now that [I]0-i have got [my]0-i terms [I]0-i will tell [you]2716-gentlemen [my]0-i reasons for making up [my]0-i mind to go . First of all , [gentlemen]2716-gentlemen , [I]0-i have been observing [you]2716-gentlemen both for the last few days , and if [you]2716-gentlemen will not think [me]0-i impertinent [I]0-i may say that [I]0-i like [you]2716-gentlemen , and believe that [we]2851-we shall come up well to the yoke together . That is something , let [me]0-i tell [you]2716-gentlemen , when [one]337-one has a long journey like this before one .[0-i]

" And now as to the journey itself , [I]97-sir henry tell [you]2716-gentlemen flatly , [Sir Henry]97-sir henry and [Captain Good]98-good , that [I]97-sir henry do not think it probable [we]2851-we can come out of it alive , that is , if [we]2851-we attempt to cross [the Suliman Mountains]29-suliman 's mountains . What was the fate of [the old Dom da Silvestra]128-da silvestra three hundred years ago ? What was the fate of [[his]128-da silvestra descendant]2853-his descendant twenty years ago ? What has been [[your]97-sir henry brother]2806-your brother 's fate ? [I]97-sir henry tell [you]2716-gentlemen frankly , [gentlemen]2716-gentlemen , that as [their]2856-their fates were so [I]97-sir henry believe [ours]2851-we will be . "[97-sir henry]

[I]0-i paused to watch the effect of [my]0-i words . [Captain Good]98-good looked a little uncomfortable , but [Sir Henry]97-sir henry 's face did not change . " [We]2851-we must take [our]2851-we chance , "[97-sir henry] [he]97-sir henry said .

" [You]2716-gentlemen may perhaps wonder , "[0-i] [I]0-i went on , " why , if [I]0-i think this , [I]0-i , who am , as [I]0-i told [you]2716-gentlemen , [a timid man]261-a timid man , should undertake such a journey . It is for two reasons . First [I]0-i am [a fatalist]2858-a fatalist , and believe that [my]0-i time is appointed to come quite without reference to [my]0-i own movements and will , and that if [I]0-i am to go to [Suliman 's Mountains]29-suliman 's mountains to be killed , [I]0-i shall go [there]2626-there and shall be killed . [God Almighty]102-god , no doubt , knows [His]102-god mind about [me]0-i , so [I]0-i need not trouble on that point . Secondly , [I]0-i am [a poor man]2860-a poor man . For nearly forty years [I]0-i have hunted and traded , but [I]0-i have never made more than a living . Well , [gentlemen]2716-gentlemen , [I]0-i do n't know if [you]2716-gentlemen are aware that the average life of [an elephant hunter]2717-an elephant hunter from the time [he]2717-an elephant hunter takes to the trade is between four and five years . So [you]2716-gentlemen see [I]0-i have lived through about seven generations of [[my]0-i class]2863-my class , and [I]0-i should think that [my]0-i time can not be far off , anyway . Now , if anything were to happen to [me]0-i in the ordinary course of business , by the time [my]0-i debts are paid there would be nothing left to support [[my]0-i son]2864-my son [Harry]97-sir henry whilst [he]97-sir henry was getting in the way of earning a living , whereas now [he]97-sir henry will be set up for five years . There is the whole affair in a nutshell . "[0-i]

" [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , who had been giving [me]0-i [his]97-sir henry most serious attention , " [your]0-i motives for undertaking an enterprise which [you]0-i believe can only end in disaster reflect a great deal of credit on [you]0-i . Whether or not [you]0-i are right , of course time and the event alone can show . But whether [you]0-i are right or wrong , [I]97-sir henry may as well tell [you]0-i at once that [I]97-sir henry am going through with it to the end , sweet or bitter . If [we]2865-we are to be knocked on the head , all [I]97-sir henry have to say is , that [I]97-sir henry hope [we]2865-we get a little shooting first , eh , Good ? "[97-sir henry]

" Yes , yes , "[355-the captain] put in [the captain]355-the captain . " [We]2865-we have [all three of [us]2865-we]2866-all three of us been accustomed to face danger , and to hold [our]2865-we lives in [our]2865-we hands in various ways , so it is no good turning back now . And now [I]355-the captain vote [we]2865-we go down to [the saloon]359-the saloon and take an observation just for luck , [you]0-i know . "[355-the captain] And [we]454-we did - through the bottom of a tumbler .

Next day [we]454-we went [ashore]455-ashore , and [I]0-i put up [Sir Henry]97-sir henry and [Captain]456-captain Good at [the little shanty [I]0-i have built on [the Berea]41-the berea]457-the little shanty i have built on the berea , and which [I]0-i call [[my]0-i home]458-my home . There are only [three rooms]459-three rooms and [a kitchen]460-a kitchen in [it]458-my home , and [it]458-my home is constructed of green brick with a galvanised iron roof , but there is [a good garden]461-a good garden with the best loquot trees in [it]461-a good garden that [I]0-i know , and some nice young mangoes , of which [I]0-i hope great things . [The curator of [the botanical gardens]299-the botanical gardens]462-the curator of the botanical gardens gave them to [me]0-i . [It]461-a good garden is looked after by [an old hunter of mine named [Jack]129-jack , whose thigh was so badly broken by a buffalo cow in [Sikukunis country]465-sikukunis country]464-an old hunter of mine named jack , whose thigh was so badly broken by a buffalo cow in sikukunis country that [he]464-an old hunter of mine named jack , whose thigh was so badly broken by a buffalo cow in sikukunis country will never hunt again . But [he]464-an old hunter of mine named jack , whose thigh was so badly broken by a buffalo cow in sikukunis country can potter about and [garden]466-garden , being [a Griqua]130-a griqua by birth . [You]467-you will never persuade [a Zulu]468-a zulu to take much interest in gardening . It is a peaceful art , and peaceful arts are not in [his]464-an old hunter of mine named jack , whose thigh was so badly broken by a buffalo cow in sikukunis country line .

[Sir Henry]97-sir henry and [Good]98-good slept in [a tent pitched in [my]0-i little grove of orange trees at the end of [the garden]470-the garden]469-a tent pitched in my little grove of orange trees at the end of the garden , for there was no room for them in [the house]471-the house , and what with the smell of the bloom , and the sight of the green and golden fruit - in [Durban]10-durban [you]467-you will see all three on the tree together - [I]0-i daresay it is [a pleasant place]472-a pleasant place enough , for [we]473-we have few mosquitos here on [the Berea]41-the berea , unless there happens to come an unusually heavy rain .

Well , to get on - for if [I]0-i do not , [Harry]97-sir henry , [you]467-you will be tired of [my]0-i story before ever [we]473-we fetch up at [[Suliman]118-suliman 's Mountains]474-suliman 's mountains - having once made up [my]0-i mind to go [I]0-i set about making the necessary preparations . First [I]0-i secured the deed from [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , providing for [you]467-you , [[my]0-i boy]266-my boy , in case of accidents . There was some difficulty about its legal execution , as [Sir Henry]97-sir henry was [a stranger here]476-a stranger here , and the property to be charged is over [the water]477-the water ; but it was ultimately got over with the help of [a lawyer]2632-a lawyer , who charged 20 for the job - a price that [I]0-i thought outrageous . Then [I]0-i pocketed [my]0-i cheque for 500 .

Having paid this tribute to [my]0-i bump of caution , [I]0-i purchased [a wagon]2634-a wagon and a span of oxen on [Sir Henry]97-sir henry 's behalf , and beauties they were . It was [a twenty - two - foot wagon with iron axles]480-a twenty - two - foot wagon with iron axles , very strong , very light , and built throughout of stink wood ; not quite a new one , having been to [the Diamond Fields]292-the diamond fields and back , but , in [my]0-i opinion , all the better for that , for [I]0-i could see that the wood was well seasoned . If anything is going to give in [a wagon]2634-a wagon , or if there is green wood in it , it will show out on the first trip . [This particular vehicle]483-this particular vehicle was what [we]484-we call [a " half - tented "[484-we] wagon]485-a " half - tented " wagon , that is to say , only covered in over the after twelve feet , leaving all the front part free for the necessaries [we]484-we had to carry with [us]484-we . In this after part were a hide " cartle , "[484-we] or bed , on which [two people]486-two people could sleep , also racks for rifles , and many other little conveniences . [I]0-i gave 125 for it , and think that it was cheap at the price .

Then [I]0-i bought a beautiful team of twenty Zulu oxen , which [I]0-i had kept [my]0-i eye on for a year or two . Sixteen oxen is the usual number for [a team]487-a team , but [I]0-i took four extra to allow for casualties . [These Zulu cattle]488-these zulu cattle are small and light , not more than half the size of the Africander oxen , which are generally used for transport purposes ; but [they]488-these zulu cattle will live where [the Africanders]489-the africanders would starve , and with a moderate load can make five miles a day better going , being quicker and not so liable to become footsore . What is more , [this lot]490-this lot were thoroughly ' salted , " that is , [they]490-this lot had worked all over [South Africa]23-south africa , and so had become proof , comparatively speaking , against red water , which so frequently destroys [whole teams of oxen]2868-whole teams of oxen when [they]2868-whole teams of oxen get on to [strange "[493-good] veldt " or grass country]2869-strange " veldt " or grass country . As for "[493-good] lung sick , " which is a dreadful form of pneumonia , very prevalent in [this country]2870-this country , [they]490-this lot had all been inoculated against it . This is done by cutting a slit in the tail of an ox , and binding in a piece of the diseased lung of [an animal which has died of the sickness]2871-an animal which has died of the sickness . The result is that [the ox sickens]2872-the ox sickens , takes the disease in a mild form , which causes its tail to drop off , as a rule about a foot from the root , and becomes proof against future attacks . It seems cruel to rob the animal of [his]493-good tail , especially in [a country where there are so many flies]2873-a country where there are so many flies , but it is better to sacrifice the tail and keep the ox than to lose both tail and ox , for a tail without an ox is not much good , except to dust with .
