[The Black Hole of [Calcutta]54-calcutta]3011-the black hole of calcutta must have been a fool to [it]3011-the black hole of calcutta ; indeed , to this moment [I]696-we do not know how [we]696-we lived through the day . There [we]696-we lay panting , and every now and again moistening [our]696-we lips from [our]696-we scanty supply of water . Had [we]696-we followed [our]696-we inclinations [we]696-we should have finished all [we]696-we possessed in the first two hours , but [we]696-we were forced to exercise the most rigid care , for if [our]696-we water failed [us]696-we [we]696-we knew that very soon [we]696-we must perish miserably .[696-we]

But everything has an end , if only [you]749-you live long enough to see it , and somehow that miserable day wore on towards evening . About three o'clock in the afternoon [we]750-we determined that [we]750-we could bear it no longer . It would be better to die walking that to be killed slowly by heat and thirst in [this dreadful hole]751-this dreadful hole . So taking each of [us]750-we a little drink from [our]750-we fast diminishing supply of water , now warmed to about the same temperature as [a man]2655-a man 's blood , [we]750-we staggered forward .

[We]750-we had then covered [some fifty miles of wilderness]753-some fifty miles of wilderness . If [the reader]502-the reader will refer to the rough copy and translation of [old da Silvestra]128-da silvestra 's map , [he]502-the reader will see that [the desert]2742-the desert is marked as measuring forty leagues across , and [the " pan bad water]3012-the " pan bad water "[502-the reader] is set down as being about in the middle of it . Now forty leagues is one hundred and twenty miles , consequently [we]750-we ought at the most to be within twelve or fifteen miles of [the water]477-the water if any should really exist .

Through the afternoon [we]750-we crept slowly and painfully along , scarcely doing more than a mile and a half in an hour . At sunset [we]750-we rested again , waiting for the moon , and after drinking a little managed to get some sleep .

Before [we]750-we lay down , [Umbopa]132-umbopa pointed out to [us]750-we [a slight and indistinct hillock on the flat surface of [the plain about eight miles away]758-the plain about eight miles away]757-a slight and indistinct hillock on the flat surface of the plain about eight miles away . At the distance it looked like [an ant - hill]759-an ant - hill , and as [I]0-i was dropping off to sleep [I]0-i fell to wondering what it could be .

With the moon [we]750-we marched again , feeling dreadfully exhausted , and suffering tortures from thirst and prickly heat . [Nobody who has not felt it]760-nobody who has not felt it can know what [we]750-we went through . [We]750-we walked no longer , [we]750-we staggered , now and again falling from exhaustion , and being obliged to call a halt every hour or so . [We]750-we had scarcely energy left in [us]750-we to speak . Up to this [Good]98-good had chatted and joked , for [he]98-good is [a merry fellow]761-a merry fellow ; but now [he]98-good had not a joke in [him]98-good .

At last , about two o'clock , utterly worn out in body and mind , [we]750-we came to [the foot of [the queer hill]763-the queer hill]762-the foot of the queer hill , or [sand koppie]764-sand koppie , which at first sight resembled [a gigantic ant - heap]765-a gigantic ant - heap about a hundred feet high , and covering at the base nearly two acres of ground .

Here [we]750-we halted , and driven to [it]766-it by [our]750-we desperate thirst , sucked down [our]750-we last drops of water . [We]750-we had but half a pint a head , and each of [us]750-we could have drunk a gallon .

Then [we]750-we lay down . Just as [I]0-i was dropping off to sleep [I]0-i heard [Umbopa]132-umbopa remark to [himself]132-umbopa in Zulu -

" If [we]750-we can not find water [we]750-we shall all be dead before the moon rises to - morrow . "[132-umbopa]

[I]0-i shuddered , hot as it was . The near prospect of such an awful death is not pleasant , but even the thought of it could not keep [me]0-i from sleeping .

1 [Readers]767-readers must beware of accepting [Mr. Quatermain]107-quatermain 's references as accurate , as , it has been found , some are prone to do . Although [his]107-quatermain reading evidently was limited , the impression produced by it upon [his]107-quatermain mind was mixed . Thus to [him]107-quatermain the Old Testament and [Shakespeare]154-shakespeare were interchangeable authorities . - [Editor]768-editor .

CHAPTER VI

WATER ! WATER !

Two hours later , that is , about four o'clock , [I]0-i woke up , for so soon as the first heavy demand of bodily fatigue had been satisfied , the torturing thirst from which [I]0-i was suffering asserted itself . [I]0-i could sleep no more . [I]0-i had been dreaming that [I]0-i was bathing in [a running stream]769-a running stream , with green banks and trees upon them , and [I]0-i awoke to find [myself]0-i in [this arid wilderness]770-this arid wilderness , and to remember , as [Umbopa]132-umbopa had said , that if [we]771-we did not find water this day [we]771-we must perish miserably . [No human creature]772-no human creature could live long without water in that heat . [I]0-i sat up and rubbed [my]0-i grimy face with [my]0-i dry and horny hands , as [my]0-i lips and eyelids were stuck together , and it was only after some friction and with an effort that [I]0-i was able to open them . It was not far from dawn , but there was none of the bright feel of dawn in the air , which was thick with a hot murkiness that [I]0-i can not describe . The others were still sleeping .

Presently it began to grow light enough to read , so [I]0-i drew out a little pocket copy of the " Ingoldsby Legends "[773-the cardinal] which [I]0-i had brought with [me]0-i , and read " [The Jackdaw of [Rheims]55-rheims]3013-the jackdaw of rheims . "[0-i] When [I]0-i got to where

" [A nice little boy]3014-a nice little boy held a golden ewer , Embossed , and filled with water as pure As any that flows between [Rheims]55-rheims and [Namur]56-namur , "[0-i]

literally [I]0-i smacked [my]0-i cracking lips , or rather tried to smack them . The mere thought of that pure water made [me]0-i mad . If [the Cardinal]773-the cardinal had been there with [his]773-the cardinal bell , book , and candle , [I]0-i would have whipped in and drunk [his]773-the cardinal water up ; yes , even if [he]773-the cardinal had filled it already with the suds of soap " worthy of washing the hands of [the Pope]3015-the pope , "[773-the cardinal] and [I]0-i knew that the whole consecrated curse of [the Catholic Church]774-the catholic church should fall upon [me]0-i for so doing . [I]0-i almost think that [I]0-i must have been a little light - headed with thirst , weariness and the want of food ; for [I]0-i fell to thinking how astonished [the Cardinal]773-the cardinal and [[his]773-the cardinal nice little boy]776-his nice little boy and [the jackdaw]777-the jackdaw would have looked to see [a burnt up , brown - eyed , grizzly - haired little elephant hunter]778-a burnt up , brown - eyed , grizzly - haired little elephant hunter suddenly bound between [them]779-them , put [his]778-a burnt up , brown - eyed , grizzly - haired little elephant hunter dirty face into the basin , and swallow every drop of the precious water . The idea amused [me]0-i so much that [I]0-i laughed or rather cackled aloud , which woke [the others]595-the others , and [they]595-the others began to rub [their]595-the others dirty faces and drag [their]595-the others gummed - up lips and eyelids apart .

As soon as [we]781-we were all well awake [we]781-we began to discuss the situation , which was serious enough . Not a drop of water was left . [We]781-we turned the bottles upside down , and licked their tops , but it was a failure ; they were dry as a bone . [Good]98-good , who had charge of the flask of brandy , got it out and looked at it longingly ; but [Sir Henry]97-sir henry promptly took it away from [him]98-good , for to drink raw spirit would only have been to precipitate the end .

" If [we]781-we do not find water [we]781-we shall die , "[98-good] [he]98-good said .

" If [we]781-we can trust to the old [Dom]128-da silvestra 's map there should be some about , "[0-i] [I]0-i said ; but [nobody]782-nobody seemed to derive much satisfaction from this remark . It was so evident that no great faith could be put in the map . Now it was gradually growing light , and as [we]781-we sat staring blankly at [each other]373-each other , [I]0-i observed [the Hottentot Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel rise and begin to walk about with [his]784-he eyes on the ground . Presently [he]784-he stopped short , and uttering a guttural exclamation , pointed to [the earth]632-the earth .[0-i]

" What is it ? "[781-we] [we]781-we exclaimed ; and rising simultaneously [we]781-we went to where [he]784-he was standing staring at the sand .

" Well , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " it is fresh Springbok spoor ; what of it ? "[0-i]

" [Springbucks]155-springbucks do not go far from water , "[784-he] [he]784-he answered in Dutch .

" No , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , " [I]0-i forgot ; and thank [God]102-god for it . "[0-i]

This little discovery put new life into [us]781-we ; for it is wonderful , when [a man]2655-a man is in a desperate position , how [he]2655-a man catches at the slightest hope , and feels almost happy . On a dark night a single star is better than nothing .

Meanwhile [Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel was lifting [his]784-he snub nose , and sniffing the hot air for all [the world]248-the world like an old Impala ram who scents danger . Presently [he]784-he spoke again .[0-i]

" [I]784-he smell water , "[784-he] [he]784-he said .

Then [we]781-we felt quite jubilant , for [we]781-we knew what a wonderful instinct [these wild - bred men]786-these wild - bred men possess .

Just at that moment the sun came up gloriously , and revealed so grand a sight to [our]781-we astonished eyes that for a moment or two [we]781-we even forgot [our]781-we thirst .

There , not more than forty or fifty miles from [us]781-we , glittering like silver in the early rays of the morning sun , soared [Sheba]121-sheba 's Breasts ; and stretching away for hundreds of miles on either side of [them]787-them ran the great [Suliman Berg]50-the suliman berg . Now that , sitting here , [I]0-i attempt to describe the extraordinary grandeur and beauty of that sight , language seems to fail [me]0-i . [I]0-i am impotent even before its memory . Straight before [us]781-we , rose two enormous mountains , the like of which are not , [I]0-i believe , to be seen in [Africa]58-africa , if indeed there are [any other such in [the world]248-the world]788-any other such in the world , measuring each of [them]790-them at least fifteen thousand feet in height , standing not more than a dozen miles apart , linked together by [a precipitous cliff of rock]791-a precipitous cliff of rock , and towering in awful white solemnity straight into the sky . These mountains placed thus , like the pillars of a gigantic gateway , are shaped after the fashion of [a woman]272-a woman 's breasts , and at times the mists and shadows beneath them take the form of [a recumbent woman , veiled mysteriously in sleep]793-a recumbent woman , veiled mysteriously in sleep . Their bases swell gently from [the plain]725-the plain , looking at that distance perfectly round and smooth ; and upon the top of each is a vast hillock covered with snow , exactly corresponding to the nipple on the female breast . [The stretch of cliff that connects [them]790-them]795-the stretch of cliff that connects them appears to be some thousands of feet in height , and perfectly precipitous , and on each flank of [them]790-them , so far as the eye can reach , extent similar lines of cliff , broken only here and there by flat table - topped mountains , something like [the world - famed one at [Cape Town]15-cape town]796-the world - famed one at cape town ; a formation , by the way , that is very common in [Africa]58-africa .

To describe the comprehensive grandeur of that view is beyond [my]0-i powers . There was something so inexpressibly solemn and overpowering about those huge volcanoes - for doubtless they are extinct volcanoes - that it quite awed [us]781-we . For a while the morning lights played upon the snow and the brown and swelling masses beneath , and then , as though to veil the majestic sight from [our]781-we curious eyes , strange vapours and clouds gathered and increased around [the mountains]2771-the mountains , till presently [we]781-we could only trace their pure and gigantic outlines , showing ghostlike through the fleecy envelope . Indeed , as [we]781-we afterwards discovered , usually they were wrapped in this gauze - like mist , which doubtless accounted for [our]781-we not having seen them more clearly before .

[[Sheba]121-sheba 's Breasts]2788-sheba 's breasts had scarcely vanished into cloud - clad privacy , before [our]781-we thirst - literally a burning question - reasserted itself .

It was all very well for [Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel to say that [he]799-he smelt water , but [we]781-we could see no signs of it , look which way [we]781-we would . So far as the eye might reach there was nothing but arid sweltering sand and karoo scrub . [We]781-we walked round [the hillock]3018-the hillock and gazed about anxiously on the other side , but it was the same story , not a drop of water could be found ; there was no indication of a pan , [a pool]3019-a pool , or a spring .[799-he]

" [You]799-he are [a fool]3020-a fool , "[0-i] [I]0-i said angrily to [Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel ; "[0-i] there is no water . "[0-i]

But still [he]799-he lifted [his]799-he ugly snub nose and sniffed .

" [I]799-he smell it , [Baas]123-baas , "[799-he] [he]799-he answered ; " it is somewhere in the air . "[799-he]

" Yes , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " no doubt it is in the clouds , and about two months hence it will fall and wash [our]781-we bones . "[0-i]

[Sir Henry]97-sir henry stroked [his]97-sir henry yellow beard thoughtfully . " Perhaps it is on [the top of [the hill]3022-the hill]3021-the top of the hill , "[97-sir henry] [he]97-sir henry suggested .

" Rot , "[98-good] said [Good]98-good ; " whoever heard of water being found at [the top of [a hill]3024-a hill]3023-the top of a hill ! "[98-good]

" Let [us]800-we go and look , "[0-i] [I]0-i put in , and hopelessly enough [we]800-we scrambled up [the sandy sides of [the hillock]3018-the hillock]801-the sandy sides of the hillock , [Umbopa]132-umbopa leading . Presently [he]799-he stopped as though [he]799-he was petrified .

" [Nanzia manzie]156-nanzia manzie ! "[98-good] that is , " Here is water ! "[799-he] [he]799-he cried with a loud voice .

[We]800-we rushed up to [him]799-he , and there , sure enough , in a deep cut or indentation on [the very top of [the sand koppie]804-the sand koppie]803-the very top of the sand koppie , was an undoubted pool of water . How it came to be in such [a strange place]805-a strange place [we]800-we did not stop to inquire , nor did [we]800-we hesitate at [its]805-a strange place black and unpleasant appearance . It was water , or a good imitation of it , and that was enough for [us]800-we . [We]800-we gave a bound and a rush , and in another second [we]800-we were all down on [our]800-we stomachs sucking up the uninviting fluid as though it were nectar fit for [the gods]806-the gods . Heavens , how [we]800-we did drink ! Then when [we]800-we had done drinking [we]800-we tore off [our]800-we clothes and sat down in [the pool]602-the pool , absorbing the moisture through [our]800-we parched skins . [You]808-you , [Harry]97-sir henry , [[my]0-i boy]266-my boy , who have [only to turn on a couple of taps to summon " hot "[810-only to turn on a couple of taps to summon " hot " and " cold " from an unseen , vasty cistern] and " cold "[810-only to turn on a couple of taps to summon " hot " and " cold " from an unseen , vasty cistern] from an unseen , vasty cistern]810-only to turn on a couple of taps to summon " hot " and " cold " from an unseen , vasty cistern , can have little idea of the luxury of that muddy wallow in brackish tepid water .

After a while [we]800-we rose from it , refreshed indeed , and fell to on [our]800-we " biltong , "[810-only to turn on a couple of taps to summon " hot " and " cold " from an unseen , vasty cistern] of which [we]800-we had scarcely been able to touch a mouthful for twenty - four hours , and ate [our]800-we fill . Then [we]800-we smoked a pipe , and lay down by the side of [that blessed pool]811-that blessed pool , under the overhanging shadow of [its]811-that blessed pool bank , and slept till noon .

All that day [we]800-we rested [there by the water]812-there by the water , thanking [our]800-we stars that [we]800-we had been lucky enough to find it , bad as it was , and not forgetting to render a due share of gratitude to the shade of [the long - departed da Silvestra , who had set its position down so accurately on the tail of [his]813-the long - departed da silvestra , who had set its position down so accurately on the tail of his shirt shirt]813-the long - departed da silvestra , who had set its position down so accurately on the tail of his shirt . The wonderful thing to [us]800-we was that [the pan]814-the pan should have lasted so long , and the only way in which [I]0-i can account for this is on the supposition that it is fed by some spring deep down in the sand .

Having filled both [ourselves]800-we and [our]800-we water - bottles as full as possible , in far better spirits [we]800-we started off again with the moon . That night [we]800-we covered nearly five - and - twenty miles ; but , needless to say , found no more water , though [we]800-we were lucky enough the following day to get a little shade behind [some ant - heaps]815-some ant - heaps . When the sun rose , and , for awhile , cleared away the mysterious mists , [Suliman]118-suliman 's Berg with [the two majestic Breasts]816-the two majestic breasts , now only about twenty miles off , seemed to be towering right above [us]800-we , and looked grander than ever . At the approach of evening [we]800-we marched again , and , to cut a long story short , by daylight next morning found [ourselves]800-we upon [the lowest slopes of [Sheba]121-sheba 's left breast]817-the lowest slopes of sheba 's left breast , for which [we]800-we had been steadily steering . By this time [our]800-we water was exhausted once more , and [we]800-we were suffering severely from thirst , nor indeed could [we]800-we see any chance of relieving it till [we]800-we reached [the snow line far , far above [us]800-we]818-the snow line far , far above us . After resting an hour or two , driven to it by [our]800-we torturing thirst , [we]800-we went on , toiling painfully in the burning heat up [the lava slopes]819-the lava slopes , for [we]800-we found that [the huge base of [the mountain]659-the mountain]820-the huge base of the mountain was composed entirely of lava beds belched from the bowels of the earth in some far past age .

By eleven o'clock [we]800-we were utterly exhausted , and , generally speaking , in a very bad state indeed . The lava clinker , over which [we]800-we must drag [ourselves]800-we , though smooth compared with some clinker [I]0-i have heard of , such as that on [the Island of [Ascension]59-ascension]822-the island of ascension , for instance , was yet rough enough to make [our]800-we feet very sore , and this , together with [our]800-we other miseries , had pretty well finished [us]800-we . A few hundred yards above [us]800-we were some large lumps of lava , and towards these [we]800-we steered with the intention of lying down beneath [their]823-their shade . [We]800-we reached them , and to [our]800-we surprise , so far as [we]800-we had a capacity for surprise left in [us]800-we , on a little plateau or [ridge close by]824-ridge close by [we]800-we saw that the clinker was covered with a dense green growth . Evidently soil formed of decomposed lava had rested there , and in due course had become the receptacle of seeds deposited by birds . But [we]800-we did not take much further interest in the green growth , for one can not live on grass like [Nebuchadnezzar]157-nebuchadnezzar . That requires a special dispensation of Providence and peculiar digestive organs .

So [we]800-we sat down under the rocks and groaned , and for one [I]0-i wished heartily that [we]800-we had never started on [this fool]825-this fool 's errand . As [we]800-we were sitting there [I]0-i saw [Umbopa]132-umbopa get up and hobble towards [the patch of green]826-the patch of green , and a few minutes afterwards , to [my]0-i great astonishment , [I]0-i perceived that [usually very dignified individual dancing and shouting like a maniac , and waving something green]827-usually very dignified individual dancing and shouting like a maniac , and waving something green . Off [we]800-we all scrambled towards [him]132-umbopa as fast as [our]800-we wearied limbs would carry [us]800-we , hoping that [he]132-umbopa had found water .

" What is it , [Umbopa]132-umbopa , [son of a fool]3025-son of a fool ? "[0-i] [I]0-i shouted in Zulu .

" It is food and water , [Macumazahn]138-macumazahn , "[132-umbopa] and again [he]132-umbopa waved the green thing .

Then [I]0-i saw what [he]132-umbopa had found . It was a melon . [We]800-we had hit upon a patch of wild melons , thousands of them , and dead ripe .

" Melons ! "[0-i] [I]0-i yelled to Good , who was next [me]0-i ; and in another minute [his]828-his false teeth were fixed in one of them .

[I]0-i think [we]800-we ate about six each before [we]800-we had done , and poor fruit as they were , [I]0-i doubt if [I]0-i ever thought anything nicer .

But melons are not very nutritious , and when [we]800-we had satisfied [our]800-we thirst with [their]829-they pulpy substance , and put a stock to cool by the simple process of cutting them in two and setting them end on in the hot sun to grow cold by evaporation , [we]800-we began to feel exceedingly hungry . [We]800-we had still some biltong left , but [our]800-we stomachs turned from biltong , and besides , [we]800-we were obliged to be very sparing of it , for [we]800-we could not say when [we]800-we should find more food . Just at this moment a lucky thing chanced . Looking across [the desert]2742-the desert [I]0-i saw a flock of about ten large birds flying straight towards [us]800-we .

" Skit , Baas , skit ! "[831-the hottentot] " Shoot , [master]3026-master , shoot ! "[831-the hottentot] whispered [the Hottentot]831-the hottentot , throwing [himself]831-the hottentot on [his]831-the hottentot face , an example which [we]800-we all followed .

Then [I]0-i saw that the birds were a flock of pauw or bustards , and that [they]829-they would pass within fifty yards of [my]0-i head . Taking one of the repeating Winchesters , [I]0-i waited till [they]829-they were nearly over [us]800-we , and then jumped to [my]0-i feet . On seeing [me]0-i the pauw bunched up together , as [I]0-i expected that [they]829-they would , and [I]0-i fired two shots straight into the thick of them , and , as luck would have it , brought one down , [a fine fellow , that weighed about twenty pounds]832-a fine fellow , that weighed about twenty pounds . In half an hour [we]800-we had a fire made of dry melon stalks , and [he]832-a fine fellow , that weighed about twenty pounds was toasting over it , and [we]800-we made such a feed as [we]800-we had not tasted for a week . [We]800-we ate [that pauw]833-that pauw ; nothing was left of [him]833-that pauw but [his]833-that pauw leg - bones and [his]833-that pauw beak , and [we]800-we felt not a little the better afterwards .

That night [we]800-we went on again with the moon , carrying as many melons as [we]800-we could with [us]800-we . As [we]800-we ascended [we]800-we found the air grew cooler and cooler , which was a great relief to [us]800-we , and at dawn , so far as [we]800-we could judge , [we]800-we were not more than about a dozen miles from [the snow line]834-the snow line . Here [we]800-we discovered more melons , and so had no longer any anxiety about water , for [we]800-we knew that [we]800-we should soon get plenty of snow . But the ascent had now become very precipitous , and [we]800-we made but slow progress , not more than a mile an hour . Also that night [we]800-we ate [our]800-we last morsel of biltong . As yet , with the exception of [the pauw]835-the pauw , [we]800-we had seen no living thing on [the mountain]659-the mountain , nor had [we]800-we come across a single spring or [stream of water]837-stream of water , which struck [us]800-we as very odd , considering the expanse of snow above [us]800-we , which must , [we]800-we thought , melt sometimes . But as [we]800-we afterwards discovered , owing to a cause which it is quite beyond [my]0-i power to explain , all the streams flowed down upon [the north side of [the mountains]2771-the mountains]838-the north side of the mountains .

Now [we]800-we began to grow very anxious about food . [We]800-we had escaped death by thirst , but it seemed probable that it was only to die of hunger . The events of the next three miserable days are best described by copying the entries made at the time in [my]0-i note - book .

" 21st May. - Started 11 a.m. , finding the atmosphere quite cold enough to travel by day , and carrying some water - melons with [us]800-we . Struggled on all day , but found [no more melons]3027-no more melons , having evidently passed out of [[their]835-the pauw district]3028-their district . Saw no game of any sort . Halted for the night at sundown , having had no food for many hours . Suffered much during the night from cold .[841-others]

" 22nd . - Started at sunrise again , feeling very faint and weak . Only made about five miles all day ; found some patches of snow , of which [we]800-we ate , but nothing else . Camped at night under [the edge of [a great plateau]3030-a great plateau]3029-the edge of a great plateau . Cold bitter . Drank a little brandy each , and huddled [ourselves]800-we together , each wrapped up in [his]3031-his blanket , to keep [ourselves]800-we alive . [Are]800-we now suffering frightfully from starvation and weariness . Thought that [Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel[841-others] would have died during the night .

" 23rd . - Struggled forward once more as soon as the sun was well up , and had thawed [our]800-we limbs a little . [We]800-we are now in a dreadful plight , and [I]840-i fear that unless [we]800-we get food this will be [our]800-we last day 's journey . But little brandy left . Good , [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , and [Umbopa]132-umbopa bear up wonderfully , but [Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel[840-i] is in a very bad way . Like most Hottentots , [he]840-i can not stand cold . Pangs of hunger not so bad , but have a sort of numb feeling about the stomach . [Others]841-others say the same . [We]842-we are now on a level with the precipitous chain , or wall of lava , linking the two Breasts , and the view is glorious . Behind [us]842-we [the glowing desert]843-the glowing desert rolls away to the horizon , and before [us]842-we lie mile upon mile of smooth hard snow almost level , but swelling gently upwards , out of the centre of which [the nipple of [the mountain]659-the mountain]844-the nipple of the mountain , that appears to be some miles in circumference , rises about four thousand feet into the sky . Not a living thing is to be seen . [God]102-god help [us]842-we ; [I]0-i fear that [our]842-we time has come . "[102-god]

And now [I]0-i will drop the journal , partly because it is not very interesting reading ; also what follows requires telling rather more fully .

All that day - the 23rd May - [we]842-we struggled slowly up the incline of snow , lying down from time to time to rest . [A strange gaunt crew]846-a strange gaunt crew [we]842-we must have looked , while , laden as [we]842-we were , [we]842-we dragged [our]842-we weary feet over [the dazzling plain]847-the dazzling plain , glaring round [us]842-we with hungry eyes . Not that there was much use in glaring , for [we]842-we could see nothing to eat . [We]842-we did not accomplish more than seven miles that day . Just before sunset [we]842-we found [ourselves]842-we exactly under the nipple of [Sheba]121-sheba 's left Breast , which towered thousands of feet into the air , [a vast smooth hillock of frozen snow]848-a vast smooth hillock of frozen snow . Weak as [we]842-we were , [we]842-we could not but appreciate the wonderful scene , made even more splendid by the flying rays of light from the setting sun , which here and there stained the snow blood - red , and crowned the great dome above [us]842-we with a diadem of glory .

" [I]98-good say , "[98-good] gasped [Good]98-good , presently , " [we]842-we ought to be somewhere near that cave [the old gentleman]3032-the old gentleman wrote about . "[98-good]

" Yes , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " if there is [a cave]3033-a cave . "[0-i]

" Come , [Quatermain]107-quatermain , "[97-sir henry] groaned [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , " do n't talk like that ; [I]97-sir henry have every faith in [the Dom]128-da silvestra ; remember the water ! [We]842-we shall find [the place]3034-the place soon . "[97-sir henry]

" If [we]842-we do n't find it before dark [we]842-we are [dead men]413-dead men , that is all about it , "[0-i] was [my]0-i consolatory reply .

For the next ten minutes [we]842-we trudged in silence , when suddenly [Umbopa]132-umbopa , who was marching along beside [me]0-i , wrapped in [his]132-umbopa blanket , and with a leather belt strapped so tightly round [his]132-umbopa stomach , to " make [his]132-umbopa hunger small , "[132-umbopa] as [he]132-umbopa said , that [his]132-umbopa waist looked like [a girl]720-a girl 's , caught [me]0-i by the arm .

" Look ! "[132-umbopa] [he]132-umbopa said , pointing towards [the springing slope of the nipple]850-the springing slope of the nipple .

[I]0-i followed [his]132-umbopa glance , and some two hundred yards from [us]842-we perceived what appeared to be a hole in the snow .

" [It]3036-it is [the cave]3037-the cave , "[132-umbopa] said [Umbopa]132-umbopa .

[We]842-we made the best of [our]842-we way to [the spot]600-the spot , and found sure enough that [the hole]852-the hole was the mouth of [a cavern]853-a cavern , no doubt the same as that of which [da Silvestra]128-da silvestra wrote . [We]842-we were not too soon , for just as [we]842-we reached shelter the sun went down with startling rapidity , leaving [the world]248-the world nearly dark , for in these latitudes there is but little twilight . So [we]842-we crept into [the cave]3037-the cave , which did not appear to be very big , and huddling [ourselves]842-we together for warmth , swallowed what remained of [our]842-we brandy - barely a mouthful each - and tried to forget [our]842-we miseries in sleep . But the cold was too intense to allow [us]842-we to do so , for [I]0-i am convinced that at this great altitude the thermometer can not have marked less than fourteen or fifteen degrees below freezing point . What such a temperature meant to [us]842-we , enervated as [we]842-we were by hardship , want of food , and the great heat of [the desert]2742-the desert , [the reader]502-the reader may imagine better than [I]0-i can describe . Suffice it to say that it was something as near death from exposure as [I]0-i have ever felt . There [we]842-we sat hour after hour through the still and bitter night , feeling the frost wander round and nip [us]842-we now in the finger , now in the foot , now in the face . In vain did [we]842-we huddle up closer and closer ; there was no warmth in [our]842-we miserable starved carcases . Sometimes one of [us]842-we would drop into an uneasy slumber for a few minutes , but [we]842-we could not sleep much , and perhaps this was fortunate , for if [we]842-we had [I]0-i doubt if [we]842-we should have ever woke again . Indeed , [I]0-i believe that it was only by force of will that [we]842-we kept [ourselves]842-we alive at all .

Not very long before dawn [I]0-i heard [the Hottentot Ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets , give a deep sigh . Then [his]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets teeth stopped chattering . [I]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets did not think anything of it at the time , concluding that [he]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets had gone to sleep . [His]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets back was resting against [mine]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets , and it seemed to grow colder and colder , till at last it felt like ice .[3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets]

At length the air began to grow grey with light , then golden arrows sped across the snow , and at last the glorious sun peeped above the lava wall and looked in upon [our]842-we half - frozen forms . Also it looked upon [Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel , sitting there amongst [us]842-we , stone dead . No wonder [his]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets back felt cold , [poor fellow]2686-poor fellow . [He]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets had died when [I]860-someone heard [him]3038-the hottentot ventv"gel , whose teeth had been chattering all night like castanets sigh , and was now frozen almost stiff . Shocked beyond measure , [we]842-we dragged [ourselves]842-we from the corpse - how strange is that horror [we]842-we mortals have of the companionship of a dead body - and left [it]862-it sitting there , its arms clasped about its knees .[860-someone]

By this time the sunlight was pouring its cold rays , for here they were cold , straight into [the mouth of [the cave]3037-the cave]858-the mouth of the cave . Suddenly [I]0-i heard an exclamation of fear from [someone]860-someone , and turned [my]0-i head .

And this is what [I]0-i saw : Sitting at the end of [the cavern]861-the cavern - it was not more than twenty feet long - was another form , of which the head rested on [its]862-it chest and the long arms hung down . [I]0-i stared at it , and saw that this too was [a dead man]863-a dead man , and , what was more , [a white man]662-a white man .

[The others]595-the others saw also , and the sight proved too much for [our]866-we shattered nerves . One and all [we]866-we scrambled out of [the cave]3037-the cave as fast as [our]866-we half - frozen limbs would carry [us]866-we .

CHAPTER VII

SOLOMON 'S ROAD

Outside [the cavern]861-the cavern [we]866-we halted , feeling rather foolish .

" [I]97-sir henry am going back , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry .

" Why ? "[98-good] asked [Good]98-good .

" Because it has struck [me]97-sir henry that - what [we]866-we saw - may be [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother . "[97-sir henry]

This was a new idea , and [we]866-we re - entered [the place]3034-the place to put it to the proof . After the bright light outside , [our]866-we eyes , weak as [they]870-they were with staring at the snow , could not pierce the gloom of [the cave]3037-the cave for a while . Presently , however , [they]870-they grew accustomed to the semi - darkness , and [we]866-we advanced towards [the dead man]872-the dead man .

[Sir Henry]97-sir henry knelt down and peered into [his]872-the dead man face .

" Thank [God]102-god , "[97-sir henry] [he]97-sir henry said , with a sigh of relief , " it is not [[my]97-sir henry brother]2648-my brother . "[97-sir henry]

Then [I]0-i drew near and looked . The body was that of [a tall man in middle life with aquiline features , grizzled hair , and a long black moustache]873-a tall man in middle life with aquiline features , grizzled hair , and a long black moustache . The skin was perfectly yellow , and stretched tightly over the bones . Its clothing , with the exception of what seemed to be the remains of a woollen pair of hose , had been removed , leaving the skeleton - like frame naked . Round the neck of the corpse , which was frozen perfectly stiff , hung a yellow ivory crucifix .

" Who on earth can it be ? "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" Ca n't [you]98-good guess ? "[98-good] asked [Good]98-good .

[I]0-i shook [my]0-i head .

" Why , [the old Dom]389-the old dom , [José da Silvestra]119-josé da silvestra , of course - who else ? "[0-i]

" Impossible , "[0-i] [I]0-i gasped ; " [he]389-the old dom died three hundred years ago . "[0-i]

" And what is there to prevent [him]389-the old dom from lasting for three thousand years in this atmosphere , [I]98-good should like to know ? "[98-good] asked [Good]98-good . " If only the temperature is sufficiently low , flesh and blood will keep fresh as New Zealand mutton for ever , and [Heaven]158-heaven knows it is cold enough here . The sun never gets in here ; [no animal]3043-no animal comes here to tear or destroy . No doubt [[his]389-the old dom slave]2769-his slave , of whom [he]389-the old dom speaks on the writing , took off [his]389-the old dom clothes and left [him]389-the old dom . [He]2769-his slave could not have buried [him]389-the old dom alone . Look ! "[98-good] [he]98-good went on , stooping down to pick up a queerly - shaped bone scraped at the end into a sharp point , " here is the ' cleft bone ' that [Silvestra]119-josé da silvestra used to draw the map with . "[98-good]

[We]874-we gazed for a moment astonished , forgetting [our]874-we own miseries in this extraordinary and , as it seemed to [us]874-we , semi - miraculous sight .

" Ay , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , " and this is where [he]98-good got [his]98-good ink from , "[97-sir henry] and [he]97-sir henry pointed to a small wound on [the Dom]128-da silvestra 's left arm . " Did [ever man]3045-ever man see such a thing before ? "[97-sir henry]

There was no longer any doubt about the matter , which for [my]0-i own part [I]0-i confess perfectly appalled [me]0-i . There [he]98-good sat , [the dead man , whose directions , written some ten generations ago]875-the dead man , whose directions , written some ten generations ago , had led [us]874-we to this spot . Here in [my]0-i own hand was the rude pen with which [he]98-good had written them , and about [his]98-good neck hung the crucifix that [his]98-good dying lips had kissed . Gazing at [him]98-good , [my]0-i imagination could reconstruct the last scene of the drama , [the traveller dying of cold and starvation]876-the traveller dying of cold and starvation , yet striving to convey to [the world]248-the world the great secret which [he]98-good had discovered : - the awful loneliness of [his]98-good death , of which the evidence sat before [us]874-we . It even seemed to [me]0-i that [I]0-i could trace in [his]98-good strongly - marked features a likeness to those of [my]0-i poor friend [Silvestre]116-silvestre [[his]98-good descendant , who had died twenty years before in [my]0-i arms]878-his descendant , who had died twenty years before in my arms , but perhaps that was fancy . At any rate , there [he]98-good sat , a sad memento of the fate that so often overtakes [those who would penetrate into the unknown]879-those who would penetrate into the unknown ; and there doubtless [he]98-good will still sit , crowned with the dread majesty of death , for centuries yet unborn , to startle the eyes of [wanderers like [ourselves]874-we]880-wanderers like ourselves , if ever any such should come again to invade [his]98-good loneliness . The thing overpowered [us]874-we , already almost perished as [we]874-we were with cold and hunger .

" Let [us]874-we go , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry in a low voice ; ' stay , [we]874-we will give [him]98-good [a companion]881-a companion , " and lifting up the dead body of [the Hottentot Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel[97-sir henry] , [he]97-sir henry placed it near to that of [the old Dom]389-the old dom . Then [he]97-sir henry stooped , and with a jerk broke the rotten string of the crucifix which hung round [da Silvestra]128-da silvestra 's neck , for [his]97-sir henry fingers were too cold to attempt to unfasten it . [I]0-i believe that [he]97-sir henry has it still . [I]0-i took the bone pen , and it is before [me]0-i as [I]0-i write - sometimes [I]0-i use it to sign [my]0-i name .

Then leaving [these two]883-these two , [the proud white man of a past age]884-the proud white man of a past age , and [the poor Hottentot]885-the poor hottentot , to keep [their]883-these two eternal vigil in the midst of the eternal snows , [we]874-we crept out of [the cave]3037-the cave into the welcome sunshine and resumed [our]874-we path , wondering in [our]874-we hearts how many hours it would be before [we]874-we were even as [they]883-these two are .

When [we]874-we had walked about half a mile [we]874-we came to [the edge of [the plateau]888-the plateau]887-the edge of the plateau , for [the nipple of [the mountain]659-the mountain]844-the nipple of the mountain does not rise out of [its]844-the nipple of the mountain exact centre , though from [the desert side]891-the desert side [it]844-the nipple of the mountain had seemed to do so . What lay below [us]874-we [we]874-we could not see , for [the landscape]421-the landscape was wreathed in billows of morning fog . Presently , however , the higher layers of mist cleared a little , and revealed , at the end of [a long slope of snow]893-a long slope of snow , [a patch of green grass]894-a patch of green grass , some five hundred yards beneath [us]874-we , through which [a stream]895-a stream was running . Nor was this all . By [the stream]896-the stream , basking in the bright sun , stood and lay a group of from ten to fifteen large antelopes - at that distance [we]874-we could not see of what species .

The sight filled [us]874-we with an unreasoning joy . If only [we]874-we could get it , there was food in plenty . But the question was how to do so . The beasts were fully six hundred yards off , a very long shot , and one not to be depended on when [our]874-we lives hung on the results .

Rapidly [we]874-we discussed the advisability of trying to stalk the game , but in the end dismissed it reluctantly . To begin with , the wind was not favourable , and further , [we]874-we must certainly be perceived , however careful [we]874-we were , against the blinding background of snow , which [we]874-we should be obliged to traverse .

" Well , [we]874-we must have a try from where [we]874-we are , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry . " Which shall it be , [Quatermain]107-quatermain , the repeating rifles or the expresses ? "[97-sir henry]

Here again was a question . The Winchester repeaters - of which [we]874-we had two , [Umbopa]132-umbopa carrying [poor Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel 's as well as [his]151-ventv"gel own - were sighted up to a thousand yards , whereas [the expresses]3046-the expresses were only sighted to three hundred and fifty , beyond which distance shooting with [them]3046-the expresses was more or less guess - work . On the other hand , if [they]3046-the expresses did hit , the express bullets , being "[132-umbopa] expanding , " were much more likely to bring the game down . It was a knotty point , but [I]132-umbopa made up [my]132-umbopa mind that [we]874-we must risk it and use the expresses .[132-umbopa]

" Let each of [us]874-we take the buck opposite to [him]897-him . Aim well at the point of the shoulder and high up , "[0-i] said [I]0-i ; " and [Umbopa]132-umbopa , do [you]132-umbopa give the word , so that [we]874-we may all fire together . "[0-i]

Then came a pause , each of [us]874-we aiming [his]897-him level best , as indeed [a man]2655-a man is likely to do when [he]897-him knows that life itself depends upon the shot .

" Fire , "[132-umbopa] said [Umbopa]132-umbopa in Zulu , and at almost the same instant the three rifles rang out loudly ; three clouds of smoke hung for a moment before [us]874-we , and a hundred echoes went flying over the silent snow . Presently the smoke cleared , and revealed - oh , joy ! - a great buck lying on its back and kicking furiously in its death agony . [We]874-we gave a yell of triumph - [we]874-we were saved - [we]874-we should not starve . Weak as [we]874-we were , [we]874-we rushed down [the intervening slope of snow]899-the intervening slope of snow , and in ten minutes from the time of shooting , that animal 's heart and liver were lying before [us]874-we . But now a new difficulty arose , [we]874-we had no fuel , and therefore could make no fire to cook them . [We]874-we gazed at [each other]373-each other in dismay .

" [Starving men]3047-starving men should not be fanciful , "[98-good] said [Good]98-good ; " [we]874-we must eat raw meat . "[98-good]

There was no other way out of the dilemma , and [our]874-we gnawing hunger made the proposition less distasteful than it would otherwise have been . So [we]874-we took the heart and liver and buried them for a few minutes in a patch of snow to cool them . Then [we]874-we washed them in the ice - cold water of [the stream]896-the stream , and lastly ate them greedily . It sounds horrible enough , but honestly , [I]0-i never tasted anything so good as that raw meat . In a quarter of an hour [we]874-we were [changed men]902-changed men . [Our]874-we life and vigour came back to [us]874-we , [our]874-we feeble pulses grew strong again , and the blood went coursing through [our]874-we veins . But mindful of the results of over - feeding on starved stomachs , [we]874-we were careful not to eat too much , stopping whilst [we]874-we were still hungry .

" Thank [Heaven]158-heaven ! "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry ; " that brute has saved [our]874-we lives . What is it , [Quatermain]107-quatermain ? "[97-sir henry]

[I]0-i rose and went to look at the antelope , for [I]0-i was not certain . It was about the size of a donkey , with large curved horns . [I]0-i had never seen one like it before ; the species was new to [me]0-i . It was brown in colour , with faint red stripes , and grew a thick coat . [I]0-i afterwards discovered that [the natives of [that wonderful country]904-that wonderful country]903-the natives of that wonderful country call [these bucks]905-these bucks " inco . "[98-good] They are very rare , and only found at a great altitude where no other game will live . This animal was fairly hit high up in the shoulder , though whose bullet brought it down [we]874-we could not , of course , discover . [I]0-i believe that [Good]98-good , mindful of [his]98-good marvellous shot at the giraffe , secretly set it down to [his]98-good own prowess , and [we]874-we did not contradict [him]98-good .

[We]874-we had been so busy satisfying [our]874-we hunger that hitherto [we]874-we had not found time to look about [us]874-we . But now , having set [Umbopa]6-umbopa to cut off as much of the best meat as [we]874-we were likely to be able to carry , [we]874-we began to inspect [our]874-we surroundings . The mist had cleared away , for it was eight o'clock , and the sun had sucked it up , so [we]874-we were able to take in [all the country before [us]874-we]906-all the country before us at a glance . [I]0-i know not how to describe the glorious panorama which unfolded itself to [our]874-we gaze . [I]0-i have never seen anything like it before , nor shall , [I]0-i suppose , again .

Behind and over [us]874-we towered [[Sheba]121-sheba 's snowy Breasts]61-sheba 's breasts , and below , some five thousand feet beneath where [we]874-we stood , lay league on [league of [the most lovely champaign country]908-the most lovely champaign country]907-league of the most lovely champaign country . Here were [dense patches of lofty forest]909-dense patches of lofty forest , there a great river wound its silvery way . To the left stretched a vast expanse of rich , undulating veld or grass land , whereon [we]874-we could just make out countless herds of game or cattle , at that distance [we]874-we could not tell which . [This expanse]910-this expanse appeared to be ringed in by [a wall of distant mountains]911-a wall of distant mountains . To the right [the country]300-the country was more or less mountainous ; that is , solitary hills stood up from [its]300-the country level , with stretches of cultivated land between , amongst which [we]874-we could see groups of [dome - shaped huts]913-dome - shaped huts . [The landscape]421-the landscape lay before [us]874-we as a map , wherein rivers flashed like silver snakes , and Alp - like peaks crowned with wildly twisted snow wreaths rose in grandeur , whilst over all was the glad sunlight and the breath of Nature 's happy life .

Two curious things struck [us]874-we as [we]874-we gazed . First , that [the country before [us]874-we]915-the country before us must lie at least three thousand feet higher than [the desert]2742-the desert [we]874-we had crossed , and secondly , that [all the rivers]917-all the rivers flowed from south to north . As [we]874-we had painful reason to know , there was no water upon the southern side of [the vast range on which [we]874-we stood]918-the vast range on which we stood , but on [the northern face]919-the northern face were many streams , most of which appeared to unite with [the great river [we]874-we could see winding away farther than [our]874-we eyes could follow]920-the great river we could see winding away farther than our eyes could follow .

[We]874-we sat down for a while and gazed in silence at this wonderful view . Presently [Sir Henry]97-sir henry spoke .

" Is n't there something on the map about [[Solomon]90-solomon 's Great Road]2828-solomon 's great road ? "[97-sir henry] [he]97-sir henry said .

[I]0-i nodded , for [I]0-i was still gazing out over [the far country]921-the far country .

" Well , look ; there it is ! "[97-sir henry] and [he]97-sir henry pointed a little to [our]874-we right .

Good and [I]0-i looked accordingly , and there , winding away towards [the plain]725-the plain , was what appeared to be [a wide turnpike road]923-a wide turnpike road . [We]874-we had not seen [it]923-a wide turnpike road at first because , on reaching [the plain]725-the plain , [it]923-a wide turnpike road turned behind [some broken country]925-some broken country . [We]874-we did not say anything , at least , not much ; [we]874-we were beginning to lose the sense of wonder . Somehow it did not seem particularly unnatural that [we]874-we should find [a sort of Roman road in [this strange land]927-this strange land]926-a sort of roman road in this strange land . [We]874-we accepted the fact , that was all .

" Well , "[98-good] said [Good]98-good , " it must be quite near [us]874-we if [we]874-we cut off to the right . Had n't [we]874-we better be making a start ? "[98-good]

This was sound advice , and so soon as [we]874-we had washed [our]874-we faces and hands in [the stream]896-the stream [we]874-we acted on it . For a mile or more [we]874-we made [our]874-we way over boulders and across patches of snow , till suddenly , on reaching the top of the little rise , [we]874-we found [the road]2952-the road at [our]874-we feet . It was [a splendid road]930-a splendid road cut out of the solid rock , at least fifty feet wide , and apparently well kept ; though the odd thing was that it seemed to begin there . [We]874-we walked down and stood on [it]2952-the road , but one single hundred paces behind [us]874-we , in the direction of [Sheba 's Breasts]61-sheba 's breasts , [it]2952-the road vanished , the entire surface of [the mountain]659-the mountain being strewn with boulders interspersed with patches of snow .

" What do [you]0-i make of this , [Quatermain]107-quatermain ? "[97-sir henry] asked [Sir Henry]97-sir henry .

[I]0-i shook [my]0-i head , [I]0-i could make nothing of the thing .

" [I]493-good have it ! "[493-good] said [Good]493-good ; " [the road]2952-the road no doubt ran right over [the range]3050-the range and across [the desert on the other side]3051-the desert on the other side , but the sand there has covered it up , and above [us]874-we [it]2952-the road has been obliterated by some volcanic eruption of molten lava . "[493-good]

This seemed a good suggestion ; at any rate , [we]874-we accepted it , and proceeded down [the mountain]659-the mountain . It proved a very different business travelling along down hill on [that magnificent pathway with full stomachs]934-that magnificent pathway with full stomachs from what it was travelling uphill over the snow quite starved and almost frozen . Indeed , had it not been for melancholy recollections of poor [Ventv"gel]151-ventv"gel 's sad fate , and of [that grim cave where [he]151-ventv"gel kept company with [the old Dom]389-the old dom]3052-that grim cave where he kept company with the old dom , [we]874-we should have felt positively cheerful , notwithstanding the sense of unknown dangers before [us]874-we . Every mile [we]874-we walked the atmosphere grew softer and balmier , and [the country before [us]874-we]915-the country before us shone with a yet more luminous beauty . As for [the road itself]3055-the road itself , [I]937-captives never saw such an engineering work , though [Sir Henry]97-sir henry said that [the great road over [the St. Gothard]3057-the st. gothard in [Switzerland]62-switzerland]3056-the great road over the st. gothard in switzerland is very similar . No difficulty had been too great for [the Old World engineer who laid it out]3058-the old world engineer who laid it out . At one place [we]935-we came to a ravine three hundred feet broad and at least a hundred feet deep . [This vast gulf]3059-this vast gulf was actually filled in with huge blocks of dressed stone , having arches pierced through them at the bottom for a waterway , over which [the road]2952-the road went on sublimely . At another place [it]2952-the road was cut in zigzags out of the side of a precipice five hundred feet deep , and in a third [it]2952-the road tunnelled through the base of an intervening ridge , a space of thirty yards or more .[937-captives]

Here [we]935-we noticed that the sides of [the tunnel]936-the tunnel were covered with quaint sculptures , mostly of mailed figures driving in chariots . One , which was exceedingly beautiful , represented a whole battle scene with a convoy of [captives]937-captives being marched off in the distance .

" Well , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry , after inspecting this ancient work of art , " it is very well to call [this [Solomon]90-solomon 's Road]3061-this solomon 's road , but [my]97-sir henry humble opinion is that [the Egyptians]159-the egyptians had been [here]2924-here before [[Solomon]90-solomon 's people]3063-solomon 's people ever set a foot on it . If this is n't Egyptian or Phoenician handiwork , [I]97-sir henry must say that it is very like it . "[97-sir henry]

By midday [we]935-we had advanced sufficiently down [the mountain]659-the mountain to search [the region where wood was to be met with]939-the region where wood was to be met with . First [we]935-we came to scattered bushes which grew more and more frequent , till at last [we]935-we found [the road]2952-the road winding through a vast grove of silver trees similar to those which are to be seen on [the slopes of [Table Mountain]63-table mountain at [Cape Town]15-cape town]941-the slopes of table mountain at cape town . [I]0-i had never before met with [them]942-them in all [my]0-i wanderings , except at [the Cape]14-the cape , and [their]942-them appearance here astonished [me]0-i greatly .

" Ah ! "[98-good] said [Good]98-good , surveying these shining - leaved trees with evident enthusiasm , " here is lots of wood , let [us]935-we stop and cook some dinner ; [I]98-good have about digested that raw heart . "[98-good]

[Nobody]782-nobody objected to this , so leaving [the road]2952-the road [we]935-we made [our]935-we way to [a stream which was babbling away not far off]945-a stream which was babbling away not far off , and soon had a goodly fire of dry boughs blazing . Cutting off some substantial hunks from the flesh of the inco which [we]935-we had brought with [us]935-we , [we]935-we proceeded to toast them on the end of sharp sticks , as one sees [the Kafirs]145-the kafirs do , and ate them with relish . After filling [ourselves]935-we , [we]935-we lit [our]935-we pipes and gave [ourselves]935-we up to enjoyment that , compared with the hardships [we]935-we had recently undergone , seemed almost heavenly .

[The brook]946-the brook , of which the banks were clothed with dense masses of a gigantic species of maidenhair fern interspersed with feathery tufts of wild asparagus , sung merrily at [our]935-we side , the soft air murmured through the leaves of the silver trees , doves cooed around , and bright - winged birds flashed like living gems from bough to bough . It was [a Paradise]947-a paradise .

The magic of [the place]3034-the place combined with an overwhelming sense of dangers left behind , and of [the promised land]949-the promised land reached at last , seemed to charm [us]935-we into silence . [Sir Henry]97-sir henry and [Umbopa]132-umbopa sat conversing in a mixture of broken English and [Kitchen Zulu]160-kitchen zulu in a low voice , but earnestly enough , and [I]0-i lay , with [my]0-i eyes half shut , upon that fragrant bed of fern and watched them .

Presently [I]0-i missed [Good]98-good , and [I]0-i looked to see what had become of [him]98-good . Soon [I]0-i observed [him]98-good sitting by [the bank of [the stream]896-the stream]950-the bank of the stream , in which [he]98-good had been bathing . [He]98-good had nothing on but [his]98-good flannel shirt , and [his]98-good natural habits of extreme neatness having reasserted themselves , [he]98-good was actively employed in making a most elaborate toilet . [He]98-good had washed [his]98-good gutta - percha collar , had thoroughly shaken out [his]98-good trousers , coat and waistcoat , and was now folding them up neatly till [he]98-good was ready to put them on , shaking [his]98-good head sadly as [he]98-good scanned the numerous rents and tears in them , which naturally had resulted from [our]952-our frightful journey . Then [he]98-good took [his]98-good boots , scrubbed them with a handful of fern , and finally rubbed them over with a piece of fat , which [he]98-good had carefully saved from the inco meat , till they looked , comparatively speaking , respectable . Having inspected them judiciously through [his]98-good eye - glass , [he]98-good put the boots on and began a fresh operation . From a little bag that [he]98-good carried [he]98-good produced a pocket - comb in which was fixed a tiny looking - glass , and in this [he]98-good surveyed [himself]98-good . Apparently [he]98-good was not satisfied , for [he]98-good proceeded to do [his]98-good hair with great care . Then came a pause whilst [he]98-good again contemplated the effect ; still it was not satisfactory . [He]98-good felt [his]98-good chin , on which the accumulated scrub of a ten days ' beard was flourishing .

" Surely , "[0-i] thought [I]0-i , " [he]98-good is not going to try to shave . "[0-i] But so it was . Taking the piece of fat with which [he]98-good had greased [his]98-good boots , Good washed it thoroughly in [the stream]896-the stream . Then diving again into the bag [he]98-good brought out a little pocket razor with a guard to it , such as are bought by [people who are afraid of cutting]954-people who are afraid of cutting [themselves]954-people who are afraid of cutting , or by [those about to undertake a sea voyage]955-those about to undertake a sea voyage . Then [he]98-good rubbed [his]98-good face and chin vigorously with the fat and began . Evidently it proved a painful process , for [he]98-good groaned very much over it , and [I]0-i was convulsed with inward laughter as [I]0-i watched [him]98-good struggling with that stubbly beard . It seemed so very odd that [a man]2655-a man should take the trouble to shave [himself]2655-a man with a piece of fat in such a place and in [our]957-our circumstances . At last [he]98-good succeeded in getting the hair off the right side of [his]98-good face and chin , when suddenly [I]0-i , who was watching , became conscious of a flash of light that passed just by [his]98-good head .

[Good]98-good sprang up with a profane exclamation if it had not been a safety razor [he]98-good would certainly have cut [his]98-good throat , and so did [I]0-i , without the exclamation , and this was what [I]0-i saw . Standing not more than twenty paces from where [I]0-i was , and ten from [Good]98-good , were [a group of men]958-a group of men . [They]958-a group of men were very tall and copper - coloured , and some of [them]958-a group of men wore great plumes of black feathers and short cloaks of leopard skins ; this was all [I]0-i noticed at the moment . In front of [them]958-a group of men stood [a youth of about seventeen]959-a youth of about seventeen , [his]959-a youth of about seventeen hand still raised and [his]959-a youth of about seventeen body bent forward in the attitude of [a Grecian statue of a spear - thrower]960-a grecian statue of a spear - thrower . Evidently the flash of light had been caused by a weapon which [he]959-a youth of about seventeen had hurled .

As [I]0-i looked [an old soldier - like man]961-an old soldier - like man stepped forward out of [the group]962-the group , and catching [the youth]963-the youth by the arm said something to [him]963-the youth . Then [they]958-a group of men advanced upon [us]964-our .

[Sir Henry]97-sir henry , [Good]493-good , and [Umbopa]132-umbopa by this time had seized [their]958-a group of men rifles and lifted them threateningly . [The party of [natives]661-natives]966-the party of natives still came on . It struck [me]0-i that [they]958-a group of men could not know what rifles were , or [they]958-a group of men would not have treated [them]958-a group of men with such contempt .

" Put down [your]595-the others guns ! "[0-i] [I]0-i halloed to [the others]595-the others , seeing that [our]964-our only chance of safety lay in conciliation . [They]595-the others obeyed , and walking to the front [I]0-i addressed [the elderly man who had checked [the youth]963-the youth]969-the elderly man who had checked the youth .

" Greeting , "[0-i] [I]0-i said in Zulu , not knowing what language to use . To [my]0-i surprise [I]0-i was understood .

" Greeting , "[971-the old man] answered [the old man]971-the old man , not , indeed , in the same tongue , but in a dialect so closely allied to it that neither [Umbopa]132-umbopa nor [myself]0-i had any difficulty in understanding [him]971-the old man . Indeed , as [we]964-our afterwards found out , the language spoken by [this people]972-this people is an old - fashioned form of the Zulu tongue , bearing about the same relationship to it that the English of [Chaucer]161-chaucer does to the English of the nineteenth century .

" Whence come [you]0-i ? "[971-the old man] [he]971-the old man went on , " who are [you]0-i ? and why are the faces of [three of [you]0-i white , and the face of the fourth as the face of [[our]964-our mother 's sons]3065-our mother 's sons]3064-three of you white , and the face of the fourth as the face of our mother 's sons ? "[971-the old man] and [he]971-the old man pointed to [Umbopa]132-umbopa . [I]0-i looked at [Umbopa]132-umbopa as [he]971-the old man said it , and it flashed across [me]0-i that [he]971-the old man was right . The face of [Umbopa]132-umbopa was like the faces of [the men before [me]0-i]973-the men before me , and so was [his]132-umbopa great form like [their]973-the men before me forms . But [I]0-i had not time to reflect on this coincidence .

" [We]964-our are [strangers]3066-strangers , and come in peace , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , speaking very slowly , so that [he]971-the old man might understand [me]0-i , " and [this man]532-this man is [[our]964-our servant]3068-our servant . "[0-i]

" [You]0-i lie , "[971-the old man] [he]971-the old man answered ; " [no strangers]3069-no strangers can cross [the mountains]2771-the mountains where all things perish . But what do [your]0-i lies matter ? - if [ye]0-i are [strangers]3066-strangers then [ye]0-i must die , for [no strangers]3069-no strangers may live in [the land of [the Kukuanas]93-the kukuanas]3073-the land of the kukuanas . It is [the king]2791-the king 's law . Prepare then to die , O [strangers]3066-strangers ! "[971-the old man]

[I]0-i was slightly staggered at this , more especially as [I]0-i saw the hands of [some of [the men]975-the men]974-some of the men steal down to [their]974-some of the men sides , where hung on each what looked to [me]0-i like a large and heavy knife .

" What does [that beggar]3076-that beggar say ? "[98-good] asked [Good]98-good .

" [He]3076-that beggar says [we]3077-we are going to be killed , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered grimly .

" Oh , [Lord]3078-lord ! "[98-good] groaned [Good]98-good ; and , as was [his]98-good way when perplexed , [he]98-good put [his]98-good hand to [his]98-good false teeth , dragging the top set down and allowing them to fly back to [his]98-good jaw with a snap . It was a most fortunate move , for next second [the dignified crowd of Kukuanas]976-the dignified crowd of kukuanas uttered a simultaneous yell of horror , and bolted back some yards .

" What 's up ? "[98-good] said I.

" It 's [his]3076-that beggar teeth , "[97-sir henry] whispered [Sir Henry]97-sir henry excitedly . " [He]3076-that beggar moved [them]975-the men . Take them out , [Good]493-good , take them out ! "[97-sir henry]

[He]97-sir henry obeyed , slipping the set into the sleeve of [his]97-sir henry flannel shirt .

In another second curiosity had overcome fear , and [the men]975-the men advanced slowly . Apparently [they]975-the men had now forgotten [their]975-the men amiable intention of killing [us]978-us .

" How is it , [O strangers]3080-o strangers , "[971-the old man] asked [the old man]971-the old man solemnly , " that [this fat man]3081-this fat man pointing to [Good]98-good , who was clad in nothing but boots and a flannel shirt , and had only half finished [his]98-good shaving , whose body is clothed , and whose legs are bare , who grows hair on one side of [his]98-good sickly face and not on the other , and who wears one shining and transparent eye - how is it , [I]971-the old man ask , that [he]98-good has teeth which move of themselves , coming away from the jaws and returning of [their]975-the men own will ? "[971-the old man]

" Open [your]98-good mouth , "[0-i] [I]0-i said to [Good]98-good , who promptly curled up [his]98-good lips and grinned at [the old gentleman]3032-the old gentleman like an angry dog , revealing to [his]98-good astonished gaze two thin red lines of gum as utterly innocent of ivories as a new - born elephant . [The audience]981-the audience gasped .

" Where are [his]98-good teeth ? "[981-the audience] [they]981-the audience shouted ; " with [our]981-the audience eyes [we]981-the audience saw them . "[981-the audience]

Turning [his]98-good head slowly and with a gesture of ineffable contempt , [Good]98-good swept [his]98-good hand across [his]98-good mouth . Then [he]98-good grinned again , and lo , there were two rows of lovely teeth .

Now [the young man who had flung the knife]982-the young man who had flung the knife threw [himself]982-the young man who had flung the knife down on the grass and gave vent to a prolonged howl of terror ; and as for [the old gentleman]3032-the old gentleman , [his]982-the young man who had flung the knife knees knocked together with fear .

" [I]982-the young man who had flung the knife see that [ye]0-i are [spirits]3082-spirits , "[982-the young man who had flung the knife] [he]982-the young man who had flung the knife said falteringly ; " did [ever man born of woman]3083-ever man born of woman have hair on one side of [his]3083-ever man born of woman face and not on the other , or a round and transparent eye , or teeth which moved and melted away and grew again ? Pardon [us]981-the audience , [O [my]982-the young man who had flung the knife lords]3084-o my lords . "[982-the young man who had flung the knife]

Here was luck indeed , and , needless to say , [I]0-i jumped at the chance .

" It is granted , "[0-i] [I]0-i said with an imperial smile . " Nay , [ye]0-i shall know the truth . [We]981-the audience come from [another world]3085-another world , though [we]981-the audience are [men such as [ye]0-i]3086-men such as ye ; [we]981-the audience come , "[0-i] [I]0-i went on , " from the biggest star that shines at night . "[0-i]

" Oh ! oh ! "[984-astonished aborigines] groaned the chorus of [astonished aborigines]984-astonished aborigines .

" Yes , "[0-i] [I]0-i went on , " [we]981-the audience do , indeed "[0-i] ; and again [I]0-i smiled benignly , as [I]0-i uttered that amazing lie . " [We]981-the audience come to stay with [you]0-i a little while , and to bless [you]0-i by [our]981-the audience sojourn . [Ye]0-i will see , [O friends]3087-o friends , that [I]0-i have prepared [myself]0-i for this visit by the learning of [your]0-i language . "[0-i]

" It is so , it is so , "[985-the chorus] said [the chorus]985-the chorus .

" Only , [[my]3032-the old gentleman lord]3088-my lord , "[3032-the old gentleman] put in [the old gentleman]3032-the old gentleman , " [thou]3089-thou hast learnt it very badly . "[3032-the old gentleman]

[I]0-i cast an indignant glance at [him]3032-the old gentleman , and [he]3032-the old gentleman quailed .

" Now [friends]3090-friends , "[0-i] [I]0-i continued , " [ye]0-i might think that after so long a journey [we]981-the audience should find it in [our]981-the audience hearts to avenge such a reception , mayhap to strike cold in death the imperious hand that - that , in short - threw a knife at the head of [him]3032-the old gentleman whose teeth come and go . "[0-i]

" Spare [him]3032-the old gentleman , [my lords]3091-my lords , "[971-the old man] said [the old man]971-the old man in supplication ; " [he]3032-the old gentleman is [[the king]2791-the king 's son]3093-the king 's son , and [I]971-the old man am [[his]3032-the old gentleman uncle]3094-his uncle . If anything befalls [him]3032-the old gentleman [his]3032-the old gentleman blood will be required at [my]971-the old man hands . "[971-the old man]

" Yes , that is certainly so , "[988-the young man] put in [the young man]988-the young man with great emphasis .

" [Ye]0-i may perhaps doubt [our]981-the audience power to avenge , "[0-i] [I]0-i went on , heedless of this by - play . " Stay , [I]0-i will show [you]0-i . Here , [thou]3095-thou dog and [slave]3096-slave addressing [Umbopa]132-umbopa in a savage tone , give [me]0-i the magic tube that speaks "[0-i] ; and [I]0-i tipped a wink towards [my]0-i express rifle .

[Umbopa]132-umbopa rose to the occasion , and with something as nearly resembling a grin as [I]0-i have ever seen on [his]132-umbopa dignified face [he]132-umbopa handed [me]0-i the gun .

" It is here , [O Lord of Lords]3097-o lord of lords , "[132-umbopa] [he]132-umbopa said with a deep obeisance .

Now just before [I]0-i had asked for the rifle [I]0-i had perceived [a little klipspringer antelope standing on a mass of rock about seventy yards away , and determined to risk the shot]989-a little klipspringer antelope standing on a mass of rock about seventy yards away , and determined to risk the shot .

" [Ye]971-the old man see that buck , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , pointing the animal out to [the party before [me]0-i]990-the party before me . " Tell [me]0-i , is it possible for [man born of woman]3098-man born of woman to kill it from here with a noise ? "[0-i]

" It is not possible , [[my]971-the old man lord]3088-my lord , "[971-the old man] answered [the old man]971-the old man .

" Yet shall [I]0-i kill [it]989-a little klipspringer antelope standing on a mass of rock about seventy yards away , and determined to risk the shot , "[0-i] [I]0-i said quietly .

[The old man]971-the old man smiled . " That [[my]971-the old man lord]3088-my lord can not do , "[971-the old man] [he]971-the old man answered .

[I]0-i raised the rifle and covered the buck . It was a small animal , and one which [a man]2655-a man might well be excused for missing , but [I]0-i knew that it would not do to miss .

[I]0-i drew a deep breath , and slowly pressed on the trigger . The buck stood still as a stone .

" Bang ! thud ! "[0-i] The antelope sprang into the air and fell on the rock dead as a door nail .

A groan of simultaneous terror burst from [the group before [us]995-our]994-the group before us .

" If [you]999-you want meat , "[0-i] [I]0-i remarked coolly , " go fetch that buck . "[0-i]

[The old man]971-the old man made a sign , and [one of [[his]971-the old man followers]998-his followers]997-one of his followers departed , and presently returned bearing the klipspringer . [I]0-i noticed with satisfaction that [I]0-i had hit it fairly behind the shoulder . [They]999-you gathered round [the poor creature]1000-the poor creature 's body , gazing at the bullet - hole in consternation .

" [Ye]999-you see , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " [I]0-i do not speak empty words . "[0-i]

There was no answer .

" If [ye]999-you yet doubt [our]995-our power , "[0-i] [I]0-i went on , " let one of [you]999-you go stand upon that rock that [I]0-i may make [him]1000-the poor creature as this buck . "[0-i]

[None of [them]999-you]1001-none of them seemed at all inclined to take the hint , till at last [[the king]2791-the king 's son]3093-the king 's son spoke .

" It is well said . Do [thou]3101-thou , [[my]0-i uncle]3102-my uncle , go stand upon the rock . It is but a buck that the magic has killed . Surely it can not kill [a man]2655-a man . "[0-i]

[The old gentleman]3032-the old gentleman did not take the suggestion in good part . Indeed , [he]3032-the old gentleman seemed hurt .

" No ! no ! "[3032-the old gentleman] [he]3032-the old gentleman ejaculated hastily , " [my]3032-the old gentleman old eyes have seen enough . These are [wizards]3104-wizards , indeed . There was a most general and hasty expression of dissent .

" Let not good magic be wasted on [our]995-our poor bodies , "[337-one] said [one]337-one ; " [we]995-our are satisfied . All the witchcraft of [[our]995-our people]3106-our people can not show the like of this . "[337-one]

" It is so , "[3032-the old gentleman] remarked [the old gentleman]3032-the old gentleman , in a tone of intense relief ; " without any doubt it is so . " So be it , "[0-i] [I]0-i said carelessly ; " all time is before [us]3122-we , for [we]3122-we do not die . [We]3122-we are ready , lead on . Beware ! "[0-i]

This magnificent address did not fail of its effect ; indeed , it might almost have been spared , so deeply were [[our]1007-our friends]1008-our friends already impressed with [our]1007-our powers .

[The old man]971-the old man made a deep obeisance , and murmured the words , " [Koom Koom]167-koom , "[971-the old man] which [I]0-i afterwards discovered was [their]1008-our friends royal salute , corresponding to [the Bayéte of [the Zulus]1011-the zulus]1010-the bayéte of the zulus , and turning , addressed [[his]971-the old man followers]998-his followers . These at once proceeded to lay hold of all [our]1007-our goods and chattels , in order to bear them for [us]1007-our , excepting only the guns , which [they]1008-our friends would on no account touch . [They]1008-our friends even seized [Good]98-good 's clothes , that , as [the reader]502-the reader may remember , were neatly folded up beside [him]98-good .

[He]98-good saw and made a dive for them , and a loud altercation ensued .

" Let not [[my]971-the old man lord]3088-my lord of the transparent Eye and the melting Teeth touch them , "[971-the old man] said [the old man]971-the old man . " Surely [[his]971-the old man slave]2769-his slave shall carry the things . "[971-the old man]

" But [I]98-good want to put 'em on ! "[98-good] roared [Good]98-good , in nervous English .

[Umbopa]132-umbopa translated .

" Nay , [[my]162-infadoos lord]3088-my lord , "[162-infadoos] answered [Infadoos]162-infadoos , " would [[my]162-infadoos lord]3088-my lord cover up [his]3088-my lord beautiful white legs although [he]3088-my lord is so dark Good has a singularly white skin from the eyes of [[his]3088-my lord servants]3136-his servants ? Have [we]3137-we offended [[my]162-infadoos lord]3088-my lord that [he]3088-my lord should do such a thing ? "[162-infadoos]

Here [I]0-i nearly exploded with laughing ; and meanwhile [one of [the men]975-the men]1015-one of the men started on with the garments .

" Damn it ! "[98-good] roared [Good]98-good , " [that black villain]3139-that black villain has got [my]98-good trousers . "[98-good]

" Look here , [Good]493-good , "[97-sir henry] said [Sir Henry]97-sir henry ; " [you]493-good have appeared in [this country]2870-this country in a certain character , and [you]493-good must live up to it . It will never do for [you]493-good to put on trousers again . Henceforth [you]493-good must exist in a flannel shirt , a pair of boots , and an eye - glass . "[97-sir henry]

" Yes , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " and with whiskers on one side of [your]493-good face and not on the other . If [you]493-good change any of these things [the people]3142-the people will think that [we]3143-our are [impostors]3144-impostors . [I]0-i am very sorry for [you]493-good , but , seriously , [you]493-good must . If once [they]3142-the people begin to suspect [us]3143-our [our]3143-our lives will not be worth a brass farthing . "[0-i]

" Do [you]0-i really think so ? "[98-good] said [Good]98-good gloomily .

" [I]97-sir henry do , indeed . [Your]493-good ' beautiful white legs ' and [your]493-good eye - glass are now the features of [[our]3143-our party]3145-our party , and as [Sir Henry]97-sir henry says , [you]493-good must live up to them . Be thankful that [you]493-good have got [your]493-good boots on , and that the air is warm . "[97-sir henry]

Good sighed , and said no more , but it took [him]98-good a fortnight to become accustomed to [his]98-good new and scant attire .

CHAPTER VIII

[WE]1017-we ENTER [KUKUANALAND]2-kukuanaland

All that afternoon [we]1017-we travelled along [the magnificent roadway]1018-the magnificent roadway , which trended steadily in a north - westerly direction . [Infadoos]162-infadoos and [Scragga]164-scragga walked with [us]1017-we , but [[their]1019-their followers]1020-their followers marched about one hundred paces ahead .

" [Infadoos]162-infadoos , "[0-i] [I]0-i said at length , " who made [this road]3146-this road ? "[0-i]

" It was made , [[my]162-infadoos lord]3088-my lord , of old time , [none]2774-none know how or when , not even [the wise woman Gagool , who has lived for generations]3149-the wise woman gagool , who has lived for generations . [We]1017-we are not old enough to remember its making . [None]2774-none can fashion [such roads]3151-such roads now , but [the king]2791-the king suffers no grass to grow upon it . "[162-infadoos]
